column1: Thou liest.

column1: Humbly on my knee I crave your blessing.

column1: Marry, and did.

column1: It is no boast, being asked, to say we are.

column1: I know his heart.
column2: I know his heart.

column1: Of so high and plenteous wit and invention!
column2: Of so high and plenuous wit and invention!

column2: He’ll speak with you, will you or not.

column1: So much for him.

column2: With patience, noble lord, as prisoners must.

column2: Was it you who did so often to kill him?

column1: Oh, he’s a lovely gentleman.
column2: Oh, he’s a lovely gentleman.

column1: Tyranny is dead!

column2: When he opens his purse to give us our reward, your conscience flies out.

column2: To be Count Malvolio!

column2: Ah, ha, my lord, this prince is not an Edward!

column2: What, must I hold a candle to my shames?

column2: Yes,” he said, “Do you fall on your face?

column2: Madam wife, they say I’ve dreamed and slept more than fifteen years.

column1: Tis known before.

column2: I agree, and I wish I had given him the best horse in Padua to start his wooing that would woo her thoroughly, wed her, and bed her, and rid the house of her!

column1: My duty hushes me.
column2: My duty is hushed.

column1: I’ll tell thee ere thou ask it me again.
column2: I’ll tell you before you ask me again.

column1: And when I rear my hand, do you the like, To fall it on Gonzalo.
column2: And when I’m holding my hand, do the same, to fall it on Gonzalo.

column1: I will plague them all, Even to roaring.
column2: I’ll plague them all, even roaring.

column1: How is ’t with me when every noise appals me?
column2: How is it with me when every noise strikes me?

column1: It is called Wye at Monmouth, but it is out of my prains what is the name of the other river.
column2: It’s called Wye at Monmouth, but it’s out of my pranks, the name of the other river.

column1: If I can fasten but one cup upon him, With that which he hath drunk tonight already, He’ll be as full of quarrel and offense As my young mistress' dog.
column2: If I can only hold one cup on him, with the one he’s drunk tonight already, he’ll be as sane and offensive as my young mistress’s dog.

column1: I will help you to ’t.
column2: I’ll help you.

column1: Good morrow to you both.
column2: Good morning to you both.

column1: Of that there’s none, or little.
column2: Of that there’s no, or little.

column1: We have seen the best of our time.
column2: We’ve seen the best of our time.

column1: Tis a pageant, To keep us in false gaze.
column2: It’s a pageant to keep us in a false view.

column1: Of this discourse we more will hear anon.— Egeus, I will overbear your will.
column2: We’ll hear more about this.—Egeus, I’ll overbear your will.

column1: I take some joy to say you are because I would be talking of her.
column2: I’m glad you’re here, because I’d like to talk about her.

column1: Some villains of my court Are of consent and sufferance in this.
column2: Some villains of my court are in a position to accept this and suffer.

column1: Let me wipe it first.
column2: Let me wipe it out first.

column1: Which is the lady I must seize upon?
column2: Which is the lady I must marry?

column1: O Ratcliffe, I have dreamed a fearful dream!
column2: Oh Ratcliffe, I’ve dreamed of a fearful dream!

column1: Thou wast provokèd by thy bloody mind, That never dream’st on aught but butcheries.
column2: You were beaten by your bloody mind, who never dreamed of killing butchers.

column1: Fall and cease.
column2: Let’s go.

column1: Go call him hither.
column2: Go call him here.

column1: Not once, nor twice, but twenty times you have.
column2: Not once, or twice, but twenty times you have.

column1: Thou wilt quarrel with a man for cracking nuts, having no other reason but because thou hast hazel eyes.
column2: You’ll fight with a man for cracking nuts, just because you have hazelnut eyes.

column1: We shall further think on ’t.
column2: We’ll think about it further.

column1: Seafaring men, sir.
column2: Seafaring men, sir.

column1: My lord, upon the platform where we watch.
column2: My lord, we’re on the platform where we’re watching.

column1: Where did you die?
column2: Where did you die?

column1: Wherefore?
column2: Why?

column1: But yet, I say, If imputation and strong circumstances Which lead directly to the door of truth Will give you satisfaction, you may have ’t.
column2: But I’m saying that if you’re satisfied with the truth, you may have.

column1: I have already.
column2: I have already.

column1: We will go walk a little in the orchard, And then to dinner.
column2: We’ll go walk a little in the orchard, then to dinner.

column1: Harpier cries, “'Tis time, ’tis time.” Round about the cauldron go, In the poisoned entrails throw.
column2: Harpier cries, “It’s time, it’s time.” Round around the cauldron go, in the poisoned entrails throw.

column1: Stephano is my name, and I bring word My mistress will before the break of day Be here at Belmont.
column2: Stephano is my name, and I’ll be here at Belmont before daybreak.

column1: What will you give us?
column2: What will you give us?

column1: Alas, poor shepherd, searching of thy wound, I have by hard adventure found mine own.
column2: I’ve found my own wounds, poor shepherd.

column1: Tis torture and not mercy.
column2: It’s torture and not mercy.

column1: Do, do.
column2: Do it.

column1: We do not come as minding to contest you, Our true intent is.
column2: We don’t come as a fool to contest you, but we’re not going to be.

column1: Where’s my knave, my fool?—Go you, and call my fool hither.
column2: Where’s my knave, my fool?—Go and call my fool here.

column1: I prithee, vent thy folly somewhere else.
column2: Please, go somewhere else to avoid your slander.

column1: Let his shames quickly Drive him to Rome.
column2: Let his shame drive him quickly to Rome.

column1: Ready.
column2: Ready.

column1: General, be advised, He comes to bad intent.
column2: General, be advised, he’s coming to bad intentions.

column1: What is she?
column2: What is she?

column1: That’s my good son.
column2: That’s my good son.

column1: But yet, alas, stood I within his grace, I would prefer him to a better place.
column2: But I’d rather him be a better place to live.

column1: If thou read this, O Caesar, thou mayst live.
column2: If you read this, Caesar, you can live.

column1: Take your time.
column2: Take your time.

column1: Why, headstrong liberty is lashed with woe.
column2: Why, the king’s freedom is slashed with sorrow.

column1: There’s no clock in the forest.
column2: There’s no clock in the forest.

column1: Then hadst thou had an excellent head of hair.
column2: Then you’d have an excellent head of hair.

column1: That is another simple sin in you, to bring the ewes and the rams together and to offer to get your living by the copulation of cattle; to be bawd to a bellwether and to betray a she-lamb of a twelvemonth to a crooked-pated old cuckoldly ram, out of all reasonable match.
column2: That’s another simple sin for you: to bring the ewes and the rams together and offer to get your life by a copulation of cattle; to be beaten to a bellwether and bet

column1: Why, ay.
column2: Yes.

column1: Nod to him, elves, and do him courtesies.
column2: Go to him, elves, and do him courtesies.

column1: It may be, these apparent prodigies, The unaccustomed terror of this night, And the persuasion of his augurers May hold him from the Capitol today.
column2: It may be that these apparent prodigies, the unaccustomed terror of this night, and the persuasion of his augurers may hold him out of the Capitol today.

column1: Bondage is hoarse, and may not speak aloud, Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies, And make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine, With repetition of “My Romeo!” It is my soul that calls upon my name.
column2: I’d tear the cave where Echo lies, and make her airy tongue more hoarse than mine, with the repetition of “My Romeo!” I’m the soul who calls upon my name.

column1: Prithee, no more.
column2: Please, don’t worry.

column1: Signior Fabian, stay you by this gentleman till my return.
column2: Signior Fabian, stay with this gentleman until I return.

column1: My liege.
column2: My liege.

column1: My Lord High Constable, the English lie within fifteen hundred paces of your tents.
column2: My Lord High Constable, the English are within fifteen hundred paces of your tents.

column1: Upon the stroke of ten.
column2: At ten.

column1: Do you consent we shall acquaint him with it, As needful in our loves, fitting our duty?
column2: Do you agree that we’ll inform him of it, as we need it to be, and as we need it?

column1: My Lord of Warwick, here is, praised be God for it, a most contagious treason come to light, look you, as you shall desire in a summer’s day.
column2: My Lord of Warwick, here comes a contagious treason to light, look at you, as you’ll want in a summer’s day.

column1: God be wi' you, princes all.
column2: God be wise, princes all.

column1: If you did wed my sister for her wealth, Then for her wealth’s sake use her with more kindness.
column2: If you married my sister for her wealth, then for her wealth’s sake, use her with more kindness.

column1: I am tied to th' stake, and I must stand the course.
column2: I’m tied to the stake, and I have to stand up.

column1: Lend thy hand And pluck my magic garment from me.
column2: Lend your hand and pluck my magic garment from me.

column1: An I may hide my face, let me play Thisbe too!
column2: If I can hide my face, let me play Thisbe too!

column1: How is ’t, brother!
column2: How is it, brother?

column1: Murder and treason!
column2: Murder and treason!

column1: Therefore speak softly.
column2: So speak softly.

column1: If he do fear God, he must necessarily keep peace.
column2: If he fears God, he must always keep peace.

column1: Desire him to go in.
column2: I’d like him to go in.

column1: Is love a tender thing?
column2: Is love a tender thing?

column1: This, Cinna.
column2: This is Cinna.

column1: Prithee, peace.
column2: Please, calm down.

column1: I call thee not.
column2: I don’t call you.

column1: The king, sir— Ay, sir, what of him?
column2: The king, sir— Yes, sir, what about him?

column1: I thank thee, good Sir John, with all my heart.
column2: Thank you, Sir John, with all my heart.

column1: I will follow you.
column2: I’ll follow you.

column1: You are an ass, you are an ass!
column2: You’re an ass, you’re an ass!

column1: Up, up, and see The great doom’s image!
column2: Up, up, and see the great doom’s image!

column1: What think you on ’t?
column2: What do you think about it?

column1: Retire we to our chamber.
column2: Retire to our room.

column1: Inquire me out some mean poor gentleman, Whom I will marry straight to Clarence' daughter.
column2: Ask me some poor gentleman who I’ll marry straight to Clarence’s daughter.

column1: I am content, so thou wilt have it so.
column2: I’m happy, you’ll get it.

column1: We are very sorry for’t.
column2: We’re very sorry for it.

column1: Twere to consider too curiously, to consider so.
column2: You’d be too curious to think about it.

column1: Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.
column2: Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.

column1: I know her by her gait.
column2: I know her by her gait.

column1: Sola, sola!
column2: Oh, yes!

column1: I am all the daughters of my father’s house, And all the brothers too—and yet I know not.
column2: I’m all the daughters of my father’s house, and all the brothers too—and yet I don’t know.

column1: He is hid at Lawrence' cell.
column2: He’s hid in Lawrence’s cell.

column1: Let him be Caesar!
column2: Let him be Caesar!

column1: What were these?
column2: What were these?

column1: Or if thou hast uphoarded in thy life Extorted treasure in the womb of earth, For which, they say, you spirits oft walk in death, Speak of it.
column2: Or if you’ve ruined your life by destroying your treasure in the earth’s womb, for which you’re often killed, tell me about it.

column1: Tis death for anyone in Mantua To come to Padua.
column2: It’s time for anyone in Mantua to come to Padua.

column1: Truly, I have him, but I would not be the party that should desire you to touch him, for his biting is immortal.
column2: I have him, but I wouldn’t be the party that wants you to touch him, because he’s immortal.

column1: I wonder if the lion be to speak.
column2: I wonder if the lion will speak.

column1: But how, my lord, shall we resist it now?
column2: But how, my lord, should we resist it now?

column1: It is the lark that sings so out of tune, Straining harsh discords and unpleasing sharps.
column2: It’s the lark that sings so out of tune, preventing harsh discords and unpleasing sharps.

column1: What grows of it, no matter.
column2: What’s going on, no matter.

column1: Signior?
column2: Signior?

column1: And what said he?
column2: And what did he say?

column1: I’ll put myself in poor and mean attire And with a kind of umber smirch my face.
column2: I’ll wear poor and mean attire and smirch my face with a smirch.

column1: I promise you, my soul is very jocund In the remembrance of so fair a dream.
column2: I promise you, my soul is very sluggish in the memory of such a fair dream.

column1: My royal cousin, teach you our princess English?
column2: My royal cousin, do you teach our princess English?

column1: There’s another garment for ’t.
column2: There’s another garment for it.

column1: All which we pine for now.
column2: All that we’re pineing for now.

column1: I must love you and sue to know you better.
column2: I must love you and sue you to know you better.

column1: Now, Signior Petruchio, how speed you with my daughter?
column2: Now, Signior Petruchio, how are you going with my daughter?

column1: We will persuade him, be it possible, To put on better ere he go to church.
column2: We’ll convince him, if it’s possible, to put on better things before he goes to church.

column1: I beseech thee, youth, Put not another sin upon my head By urging me to fury.
column2: I beg you, young man, don’t put another sin on my head by telling me to fury.

column1: Thy death and fortunes bid thy followers fly.
column2: Your death and your fortunes will help your followers fly.

column1: Ay, do.
column2: Yes, do.

column1: Do you misdoubt This sword and these my wounds?
column2: Do you misdoubt this sword and these wounds?

column1: I’ll then nor give nor hazard aught for lead.
column2: I won’t give or risk anything for lead.

column1: The selfsame name, but one of better nature.
column2: The same name, but one of better nature.

column1: A friend.
column2: A friend.

column1: Prince John is this morning secretly stolen away.
column2: Prince John has been stolen this morning secretly.

column1: Not being Fortune, he’s but Fortune’s knave, A minister of her will.
column2: Not being Fortune, he’s just Fortune’s king, a minister of her will.

column1: Nay, I care not for their names.
column2: No, I don’t care about their names.

column1: Wrong I mine enemies?
column2: Wrong I’m my enemies?

column1: Do so, good Messala.
column2: Do so, Messala.

column1: Tis now the very witching time of night, When churchyards yawn and hell itself breathes out Contagion to this world.
column2: It’s the time of night for witching, when churchyards are yawn and hell itself breathes out the world.

column1: The former Hero!
column2: The former Hero!

column1: All thy other titles thou hast given away that thou wast born with.
column2: All your other titles you’ve given away that you were born with.

column1: Oh, think’st thou we shall ever meet again?
column2: Oh, do you think we’ll ever meet again?

column1: Within this three mile may you see it coming; I say, a moving grove.
column2: Within a mile you can see it coming, I say, a moving grove.

column1: They are free men, but I am banishèd.
column2: They’re free men, but I’m not.

column1: But come what sorrow can, It cannot countervail the exchange of joy That one short minute gives me in her sight.
column2: But if you come to see what sorrow can do, it can’t counteract the joy I’ve had in her sight for a minute.

column1: What’s that good for?
column2: What’s that good for?

column1: My Lord of Warwick and my brother Gloucester, Follow Fluellen closely at the heels.
column2: My Lord of Warwick and my brother Gloucester, follow Fluellen closely at the heels.

column1: Get horses for your mistress.
column2: Get horses for your mistress.

column1: Let this fellow Be nothing of our strife.
column2: Let this fellow be nothing from our fight.

column1: I heard nothing.
column2: I didn’t hear anything.

column1: Kind souls, what, weep you when you but behold Our Caesar’s vesture wounded?
column2: Kind souls, what, are you crying when you see Caesar’s vesture wounded?

column1: Messala, I have here receivèd letters That young Octavius and Mark Antony Come down upon us with a mighty power, Bending their expedition toward Philippi.
column2: Messala, I’ve received letters that young Octavius and Mark Antony come down upon us with a powerful power, bending their expedition toward Philippi.

column1: Thy face is mine, and thou hast slandered it.
column2: Your face is mine, and you’ve slapped it.

column1: And all for nothing— For Hecuba!
column2: And for nothing— For Hecuba!

column1: I dare not, sir.
column2: I don’t dare, sir.

column1: Their course of love, the tidings of her death.
column2: Their love course, the tidal of her death.

column1: You say well.
column2: You’re right.

column1: What, my gracious lord?
column2: What, my gracious lord?

column1: Ay, to the proof, as mountains are for winds, That shakes not, though they blow perpetually.
column2: Yes, as long as mountains are for wind, they don’t shake, even if they blow perpetually.

column1: This sword but shown to Caesar, with this tidings, Shall enter me with him.
column2: This sword, shown to Caesar, will be able to enter me with this sword.

column1: Not i' th' stocks, fool.
column2: Not in the stocks, fool.

column1: Without, my lord; guarded, to know your pleasure.
column2: Without you, my lord, guarded, to know what you’re doing.

column1: Sir, are not you my father?
column2: Sir, aren’t you my father?

column1: I’ll be before thee.
column2: I’ll be there.

column1: It’s the wind.
column2: It’s the wind.

column1: By this leek, I will most horribly revenge.
column2: By this leek, I’ll be terribly revenged.

column1: I thank you, sir.
column2: Thank you, sir.

column1: Stay not to answer me, but get thee gone.
column2: Don’t stay to answer me, but get out of here.

column1: But what of Cicero?
column2: But what about Cicero?

column1: My father compounded with my mother under the dragon’s tail and my nativity was under Ursa Major, so that it follows I am rough and lecherous.
column2: My father was surrounded with my mother under the dragon’s tail, and my nativity was under Ursa Major, so I’m rough and lecherous.

column1: In his tail.
column2: In his tail.

column1: Excellent good.
column2: Good.

column1: And died that day when Viola from her birth Had numbered thirteen years.
column2: And died that day, when Viola died from her birth thirteen years ago.

column1: And here I stand, both to impeach and purge, Myself condemnèd and myself excused.
column2: And here I stand, both to impeach and purge, condemning myself and excused myself.

column1: I see you do not mean to part with her, Or else you like not of my company.
column2: I see you don’t want to join her, or else you don’t like my company.

column1: I wear it for a memorable honor, For I am Welsh, you know, good countryman.
column2: I wear it for a memorable honor, because I am Welsh, you know, good countryman.

column1: What sayst thou to him?
column2: What do you say to him?

column1: Is my lord angry?
column2: Is my lord angry?

column1: Let 'em enter.
column2: Let’s go.

column1: I’ll call upon you straight.
column2: I’ll call you straight away.

column1: If I should be?
column2: If I were, what would I be?

column1: But those that understood him smiled at one another and shook their heads.
column2: But those who understood him smiled at each other and shook their heads.

column1: I have forgot why I did call thee back.
column2: I’ve forgotten why I called you back.

column1: How say you, sir?
column2: What do you say, sir?

column1: Oh, then I see that madmen have no ears.
column2: Oh, then I see that madmen have no ears.

column1: So haply are they friends to Antony.
column2: They’re friends to Antony.

column1: Lucius!
column2: Lucius!

column1: Ay, and he’ll tame her.
column2: Yes, and he’ll tame her.

column1: Know him I shall, I am well sure of it.
column2: I will know him, I’m sure of it.

column1: Art thou some god, some angel, or some devil That makest my blood cold and my hair to stare?
column2: Are you a god, an angel, or a devil who makes my blood cold and my hair to stare?

column1: For I am he am born to tame you, Kate, And bring you from a wild Kate to a Kate Conformable as other household Kates.
column2: I’m born to tame you, Kate, and bring you from a wild Kate to a Kate that’s as suited to other household Kates.

column1: See, who comes here?
column2: Who’s coming?

column1: What malice was between you?
column2: What was the trouble between you and me?

column1: Good Father, I beseech you on my knees, Hear me with patience but to speak a word.
column2: Good Father, I beg you to kneel, listen to me with patience.

column1: We’ll know all our fortunes.
column2: We’ll know all about our fortunes.

column1: I’ll catch it ere it come to ground.
column2: I’ll catch it before it comes to ground.

column1: Madam, I had rather— I know your lady does not love her husband.
column2: Madam, I’d rather— I know your lady doesn’t love her husband.

column1: Truly, I would the gods had made thee poetical.
column2: I wish the gods had made you poetical.

column1: And this way have you well expounded it.
column2: And you’ve done well in this way.

column1: This jest shall cost me some expense.
column2: This slut will cost me some money.

column1: He leads himself.
column2: He’s leading himself.

column1: Tis so; and that self chain about his neck Which he forswore most monstrously to have.
column2: It’s so, and he’s wearing a self-chain around his neck that he’s forsaid monstrously.

column1: I wonder at this haste, that I must wed Ere he, that should be husband, comes to woo.
column2: I wonder at this moment that I have to marry him, who should be husband, and come to woo me.

column1: I have a head, sir, that will find out logs, And never trouble Peter for the matter.
column2: I have a head that will find logs, and I’ll never bother Peter for the matter.

column1: It is worth the pains.
column2: It’s worth the pains.

column1: And I would I could find in my heart that I had not a hard heart, for truly I love none.
column2: And I wish I could find out that I had no hard heart, because I really don’t love anyone.

column1: Bring me to Antony.
column2: Bring me to Antony.

column1: Returned so soon?
column2: Returned so soon?

column1: Pisa, renownèd for grave citizens, Gave me my being and my father first, A merchant of great traffic through the world, Vincentio, come of the Bentivolii.
column2: Pisa, renamed for grave citizens, gave me my father and my being first, a merchant of great traffic through the world, Vincentio, come from the Bentivolii.

column1: Madam, I have a touch of your condition, Which cannot brook the accent of reproof.
column2: Madam, I have a touch of your condition, which can’t be reproofed.

column1: I see him rouse himself To praise my noble act.
column2: I see him rouse himself to praise my noble act.

column1: Give me a torch.
column2: Give me a torch.

column1: No, Corin, being old, thou canst not guess, Though in thy youth thou wast as true a lover As ever sighed upon a midnight pillow.
column2: No, Corin, you can’t guess, even though you were as true a lover in your youth as ever sighed on a midnight pillow.

column1: And so they parted.
column2: And so they sat down.

column1: By my faith, he is very swift and sententious.
column2: I swear he’s very swift and sententious.

column1: Not this, but troubles of the marriage bed.
column2: Not this, but the marriage bed.

column1: Will you speak well of him that killed your cousin?
column2: Will you speak well about the man who killed your cousin?

column1: Then wherefore should I doubt?
column2: Why should I doubt it?

column1: You are to blame, my lord, to rate her so.
column2: You’re to blame for not telling her to.

column1: Then you’ll buy 'em to sell again.
column2: Then you’ll buy them to sell again.

column1: What’s your name, friend?
column2: What’s your name, friend?

column1: I know he would not be a wolf But that he sees the Romans are but sheep.
column2: I know he wouldn’t be a wolf, but I see that the Romans are sheep.

column1: Shine out, fair sun, till I have bought a glass, That I may see my shadow as I pass.
column2: Shine out, fair sun, until I’ve bought a glass, so I can see my shadow as I pass.

column1: Tomorrow will I send.
column2: Tomorrow I’ll send you.

column1: He hath been out nine years, and away he shall again.
column2: He’s been out for nine years, and he’ll be out again.

column1: And even now, but now, This house, these servants, and this same myself Are yours, my lord’s.
column2: And now, but now, this house, these servants, and this same myself are yours, my lord’s.

column1: I go, sir, but I would not have you to think that my desire of having is the sin of covetousness.
column2: I’m going, sir, but I wouldn’t want you to think that my desire to have is the sin of covet.

column1: The king would speak with Cornwall.
column2: The king would speak with Cornwall.

column1: Whisper her ear and tell her I and Ursula Walk in the orchard, and our whole discourse Is all of her.
column2: Whisper her ear and tell her I and Ursula walk in the orchard, and our entire discourse is about her.

column1: What news?
column2: What news do you have?

column1: Was ever woman in this humor wooed?
column2: Was a woman ever wooed by this humor?

column1: How goes it with my brave Mark Antony?
column2: How is it with my brave Mark Antony?

column1: What do you mean?
column2: What do you mean?

column1: O me, O me!
column2: Oh, my, Oh my!

column1: Tis well you offer it behind her back.
column2: It’s good you’re offering it behind her back.

column1: He fears, my lord, you mean no good to him.
column2: He fears you’re not good enough to him, my lord.

column1: What, shall I groan and tell thee?
column2: What, should I groan and tell you?

column1: Machinations, hollowness, treachery, and all ruinous disorders follow us disquietly to our graves.
column2: We’re going to die in our graves with a squeak machination, hollowness, treachery, and all the ruined things.

column1: Would they had stayed.
column2: They wish they had stayed.

column1: Let us go.
column2: Let’s go.

column1: True,” said she, “a fine little one.” “No,” said I, “a great wit.” “Right,” says she, “a great gross one.” “Nay,” said I, “a good wit.” “Just,” said she, “it hurts nobody.” “Nay,” said I, “the gentleman is wise.” “Certain,” said she, “a wise gentleman.” “Nay,” said I, “he hath the tongues.” “That I believe,” said she, “for he swore a thing to me on Monday night, which he forswore on Tuesday morning; there’s a double tongue, there’s two tongues.” Thus did she an hour together transshape thy particular virtues.
column2: “No,” said she, “a fine little man.” “No,” said I, “a great wit.” “Right,” says she, “a great gross one.” “No,” said I, “a good wit.”

column1: I commend your pains, And every one shall share i' th' gains.
column2: I’ll give you the best advice.

column1: Tis certain there’s not a boy left alive, and the cowardly rascals that ran from the battle ha' done this slaughter.
column2: It’s certain there’s no boy left alive, and the cowardly rascals who ran away from the battle have done this slaughter.

column1: Indeed?
column2: Yes, really?

column1: In Sicyon.
column2: In Sicyon.

column1: And they have conspired together.
column2: And they’ve conspired together.

column1: Where is Antony?
column2: Where’s Antony?

column1: Stand, ho!
column2: Stand up!

column1: Search, seek, and know how this foul murder comes.
column2: Search, search, and know how this horrible murder comes about.

column1: Think and die.
column2: Think and die.

column1: I do not know.
column2: I don’t know.

column1: Very well.
column2: Very well.

column1: Go, you wild bedfellow, you cannot soothsay.
column2: Go, you wild bedfellow, you can’t soothsay.

column1: And false.
column2: And false.

column1: I would not marry her, though she were endowed with all that Adam had left him before he transgressed.
column2: I wouldn’t marry her, even if she were given all the money Adam had left him before he transgressed.

column1: His name is Balthazar.
column2: His name is Balthazar.

column1: Coraggio, bully-monster,  If these be true spies which I wear in my head, here’s a goodly sight.
column2: Coraggio, bully-monster, if these are true spies I wear in my head, here’s a good sight.

column1: My cousin Westmoreland?
column2: My cousin Westmoreland?

column1: The folly of this island.
column2: The fright of this island.

column1: Wherefore weep I then?
column2: Why do you cry then?

column1: Bless thee, Bottom, bless thee.
column2: Bless you, Bottom, bless you.

column1: I but believe it partly, For I am fresh of spirit and resolved To meet all perils very constantly.
column2: I’m not sure, because I’m very happy and determined to face all dangers very quickly.

column1: Cassio’s my worthy friend— My lord, I see you’re moved.
column2: Cassio’s my worthy friend— My lord, I see you’re moved.

column1: What’s the matter?
column2: What’s the matter?

column1: And I know not what’s spent in the search.
column2: And I don’t know what’s going on in the search.

column1: Besides, I have some business in the town.
column2: Besides, I have some business in the town.

column1: Do you like this haste?
column2: Do you like this rush?

column1: Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth, Unapt to toil and trouble in the world, But that our soft conditions and our hearts Should well agree with our external parts?
column2: Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth, unsuited to toil and trouble in the world, but that our soft conditions and our hearts should be well aligned with our external parts?

column1: Made you no more offense but what you speak of?
column2: Did you have any more offense than what you’re talking about?

column1: I hope this reason stands for my excuse.
column2: I hope this is the reason I’m going to excuse.

column1: I tell you ’tis not very well.
column2: I tell you that it’s not very well.

column1: Therefore another prologue must tell he is not a lion.
column2: So another prologue must tell him he’s not a lion.

column1: Are not these woods More free from peril than the envious court?
column2: Aren’t these forests more protected from danger than the envious court?

column1: What shall be our sport, then?
column2: What should we do, then?

column1: Their great guilt, Like poison given to work a great time after, Now 'gins to bite the spirits.
column2: Their great guilt, like poison given to work a great time afterward, has begun to bite the spirits.

column1: He is at hand, and Pindarus is come To do you salutation from his master.
column2: He’s at hand, and Pindarus’s coming to greet you from his master.

column1: Thou, why, thou wilt quarrel with a man that hath a hair more or a hair less in his beard than thou hast.
column2: You’re going to fight with a man who has a more or a less beard than you have.

column1: Whilst he stood up and spoke, He was my master, and I wore my life To spend upon his haters.
column2: While he stood up and spoke, he was my master, and I wore my life to spend on his haters.

column1: Send for the county.
column2: Send for the county.

column1: Well, I’ll be revenged as I may.
column2: Well, I’ll be revenged as I can.

column1: Are you full of them?
column2: Are you full of them?

column1: My lady charged my duty in this business.
column2: My lady was responsible for this business.

column1: But leave it all to God.
column2: But let it go to God.

column1: A sailor’s wife had chestnuts in her lap, And munched, and munched, and munched.
column2: A sailor’s wife had chestnuts in her lap and munched, munched, and munched.

column1: Touch her soft mouth, and march.
column2: Touch her soft mouth and march.

column1: Oh, he is even in my mistress' case, Just in her case.
column2: Oh, he’s just in my mistress’s case, just in her case.

column1: Why, sir, cobble you.
column2: Why, sir, cobble you.

column1: And here will rest me.
column2: And here will rest me.

column1: There are no tongues else for ’s turn.
column2: There are no other words for the turn.

column1: What, is Brutus sick, And will he steal out of his wholesome bed, To dare the vile contagion of the night And tempt the rheumy and unpurgèd air To add unto his sickness?
column2: Is Brutus sick, and will he steal out of his wholesome bed, to dare the vile nightfall and tempt the rheumy and unpurgised air to add to his sickness

column1: If a bloody coxcomb be a hurt, you have hurt me.
column2: If a bloody coxcomb is a hurt, you’ve hurt me.

column1: O heavens!
column2: Oh heavens!

column1: You’ll have your nephews neigh to you.
column2: You’ll see your nephews neighing to you.

column1: Because we come to do you service and you think we are ruffians, you’ll have your daughter covered with a Barbary horse.
column2: Because we come to do you service and you think we’re ruffians, you’ll have your daughter covered with a barbary horse.

column1: I never did like molestation view On the enchafèd flood.
column2: I never liked the idea of molestation in the flood.

column1: We are two lions littered in one day, And I the elder and more terrible.
column2: We’re two lions littered in one day, and I’m the older and more terrible.

column1: This is the motley-minded gentleman that I have so often met in the forest.
column2: This is the sluggish gentleman I’ve met so often in the forest.

column1: Come.
column2: Come on.

column1: Ah, welladay!
column2: Ah, goodbye!

column1: Let me hire him too.—Here’s my coxcomb.
column2: Let me hire him too.—Here’s my sneezing.

column1: Now I must To the young man send humble treaties, dodge And palter in the shifts of lowness, who With half the bulk o’ th’ world played as I pleased, Making and marring fortunes.
column2: Now I have to send humble treaties to the young man, who dodges and scolds the sluggish world, making and sluggish fortunes.

column1: How fondly dost thou reason!
column2: How fondly do you reason?

column1: Here’s sport indeed!
column2: Yes, here’s a sport!

column1: What’s the matter?
column2: What’s the matter?

column1: Good thou, save me a piece of marchpane, and, as thou loves me, let the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell.—Antony and Potpan!
column2: You, save me a piece of sand, and, as you love me, let the porter let in Susan Grindstone and Nell.—Antony and Potpan!

column1: I fear I wrong the honorable men Whose daggers have stabbed Caesar.
column2: I’m afraid I’m wronging the honorable men who have stabbed Caesar.

column1: By your patience, no.
column2: No, you’re patient.

column1: What, what, good cheer!
column2: What, what, good cheer!

column1: I am aweary.
column2: I’m tired.

column1: You tell us the manner of the wrestling.
column2: You tell us the way of the wrestling.

column1: If we are marked to die, we are enough To do our country loss; and if to live, The fewer men, the greater share of honor.
column2: If we’re marked to die, we’re enough to do our country’s loss.

column1: Give me leave awhile.
column2: Give me permission for a while.

column1: Oh, out of that “no hope” What great hope have you!
column2: Oh, out of that “no hope” you have so much hope!

column1: This, this All Souls' Day to my fearful soul Is the determined respite of my wrongs.
column2: This, this All Souls' Day is the perfect excuse for my wrongdoing.

column1: Why, my young cousin?
column2: Why, my young cousin?

column1: I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.
column2: I’m bothering you too much, but you’re willing.

column1: Now Romeo is beloved and loves again, Alike bewitchèd by the charm of looks, But to his foe supposed he must complain, And she steal love’s sweet bait from fearful hooks.
column2: Romeo is now beloved and loves again, as if he was beaten by the charm of looks, but he’s supposed to complain to his foe, and she steals love’s sweet bait from fearful hook

column1: Hold you, there is a groat to heal your pate.
column2: Hold on, there’s a groat to heal your wounds.

column1: I might ask you for your commission, but I do take thee, Orlando, for my husband.
column2: I might ask you for your commission, but I take you, Orlando, for my husband.

column1: Tomorrow, Caesar, I shall be furnished to inform you rightly Both what by sea and land I can be able To front this present time.
column2: Tomorrow, Caesar, I’ll be able to tell you rightly what I can do on land and sea at this moment.

column1: Lord, let me never have a cause to sigh, Till I be brought to such a silly pass!
column2: Lord, let me never have a reason to sigh until I’ve been brought to such a silly pass!

column1: You have of late stood out against your brother, and he hath ta'en you newly into his grace, where it is impossible you should take true root but by the fair weather that you make yourself.
column2: You’ve stood out against your brother, and he has gotten you into his grace, where it’s impossible to take true root only by the weather that you’re making yourself.

column1: Now, by Saint Peter’s Church and Peter too, He shall not make me there a joyful bride.
column2: Now, by Saint Peter’s Church and Peter too, he won’t make me a joyful bride here.

column1: Ay, you have been a mouse-hunt in your time, But I will watch you from such watching now.
column2: Yes, you’ve been a mouse hunter in your time, but I’ll watch you out now.

column1: All my pretty ones?
column2: All my pretty ones?

column1: Caesar and Antony have ever won More in their officer than person.
column2: Caesar and Antony have ever won more in their officers than in their person.

column1: I hate ingratitude more in a man Than lying, vainness, babbling, drunkenness, Or any taint of vice whose strong corruption Inhabits our frail blood—    O heavens themselves!
column2: I hate ingratitude more than lying, vainness, babbling, drunkenness, or any other taint of evil whose corruption inflicts our frail blood— Oh heavens!

column1: Past question, for thou seest it will not curl by nature.
column2: Question, because you see it won’t curl by nature.

column2: Will Caesar speak?

column2: When I name him, let it be your job to praise him more than any man deserves.

column1: If more, the more thou’st wronged me.
column2: If you’re more serious, the more you’ve wronged me.

column1: I will o'erlook thy paper.

column1: Oh, thereby hangs a tail.

column1: I ne'er saw this before.

column1: I see the business.
column2: I see the business.

column2: Can you tell if Rosalind, the duke’s daughter, is banished with her father?

column2: Come on, my sweet Kate.

column1: Thou mightst have done this without thy beard and gown.
column2: You could have done this without your beard and gown.

column1: Were not my doors locked up and I shut out?
column2: Didn’t my doors lock up and I’ve shut out?

column2: Now go to the door and stay there until we call.

column2: The constable of France.

column1: I will not stay to offend you.

column2: Please, keep it in.

column1: The town sounds a parley.

column1: I am paid for ’t now.
column2: I’m paid for it now.

column1: Sweet, so would I.
column2: Sweet, so would I.

column2: Will you go, sister?—Shepherd, ply her hard.

column2: I will, my liege, as I live.

column2: How are you coming from the bridge, Fluellen?

column1: How is ’t, my noble lord?
column2: How is it, my noble lord?

column2: So, if your four negatives make your two affirmatives, then I’ll be worse for my friends and better for my enemies.

column2: Come on, then.

column2: If I had been a man of any occupation, if I hadn’t taken him at a word, I’d go to hell among the rogues.

column1: Then there’s hope a great man’s memory may outlive his life half a year.

column1: I might have saved her.
column2: I could have saved her.

column1: More to know Did never meddle with my thoughts.

column2: Master Malvolio?

column2: If they aren’t, let them hang themselves in their own straps.

column1: Silver.
column2: Silver.

column1: Here, sirrah Grumio.
column2: Here, sirah Grumio.

column2: My father had a daughter who loved a man as much as it could be, perhaps if I were a woman, then you should be your lord.

column1: Do you not hear me speak?
column2: Don’t you hear me speak?

column1: If you be pleased, retire into my cell And there repose.
column2: If you’re happy, go back to my cell and go back there.

column1: An ’twere to me, I should be mad at it.
column2: If it were to me, I’d be mad at it.

column1: Heaven rest them now.
column2: Heaven rest them now.

column1: Ay, if I be alive and your mind hold and your dinner worth the eating.
column2: Yes, if I’m alive and your mind is holding and your dinner worthy of the meal.

column1: He came too late.
column2: He came too late.

column1: Your cake there is warm within; you stand here in the cold.
column2: Your cake inside is warm, and you’re standing here in the cold.

column1: Know’st thou this country?
column2: Do you know this country?

column1: What, shall I be appointed hours as though, belike, I knew not what to take and what to leave, ha?

column1: I will bite my thumb at them, which is a disgrace to them, if they bear it.
column2: I’ll bite my thumb at them, which is a shame to them, if they bear it.

column2: And when your honors mean to solemnize the deal of your faith, I beg you to marry me too.

column1: Give mine the benefit of seigniory, And let my griefs frown on the upper hand.
column2: Give me the benefit of severiory, and let my grief scream on the upper hand.

column1: I will not be sworn but love may transform me to an oyster, but I’ll take my oath on it, till he have made an oyster of me, he shall never make me such a fool.
column2: I’ll swear that love can transform me into an oyster, but I’ll take my oath on it until he’s made an oyster of me, and he’ll never make me such a fool.

column1: But while thou livest, keep a good tongue in thy head.
column2: But while you’re alive, keep a good tongue in your head.

column1: Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause, Lest I be laughed at when I tell them so.
column2: Most mighty Caesar, let me know some reason, so I won’t be laughed at when I tell them so.

column1: Six or seven thousand is their utmost power.
column2: Six or seven thousand are their greatest powers.

column1: Is now become a god, and Cassius is A wretched creature and must bend his body If Caesar carelessly but nod on him.

column1: County Claudio, when mean you to go to church?
column2: County Claudio, when are you going to church?

column1: Pronounce it for me, sir, to all our friends, For my heart speaks they are welcome.
column2: Tell all our friends to do it for me, sir, because my heart says they’re welcome.

column1: Very good.
column2: Very good.

column1: O, yes, my lord, but very idle words.
column2: Oh yes, my lord, but very idle words.

column1: An if thou couldst, thou couldst not make him live.
column2: If you could, you couldn’t make him live.

column1: What, rouse thee, man!
column2: What, please, man!

column1: I to the world am like a drop of water That in the ocean seeks another drop, Who, falling there to find his fellow forth, Unseen, inquisitive, confounds himself.
column2: I’m like a drop of water that’s looking for another drop in the ocean, who, falling there to find his fellow, unseen, inquisitive, confounds himself.

column1: Thou know’st my lodging.
column2: You know my place.

column1: Tybalt is gone, and Romeo banishèd.
column2: Tybalt is gone, and Romeo has been banned.

column1: Buy food, and get thyself in flesh.— Come, cordial and not poison, go with me To Juliet’s grave, for there must I use thee.
column2: Get food and get yourself in flesh.—Come with me, cordial and not poison, to Juliet’s grave, because I have to use you there.

column1: So do the kings of France unto this day, Howbeit they would hold up this Salic law To bar your Highness claiming from the female And rather choose to hide them in a net Than amply to imbar their crooked titles Usurped from you and your progenitors.
column2: The kings of France would hold up this Salic law to stop your Highness from claiming the female and rather hide them in a net than to imbar their crooked titles from you and your descendants.

column1: Oh, treble woe Fall ten times treble on that cursèd head, Whose wicked deed thy most ingenious sense Deprived thee of!
column2: Oh, treble pain is ten times more painful on that slurdy head, who your wicked sense has deprived you of!

column1: To save her life, I’ll say she is not so.
column2: I’ll say she’s not so.

column1: That now I will have—that’s the humor of it.
column2: I’ll have it now—that’s the humor of it.

column1: Need you my help?
column2: Do you need my help?

column1: Tremblingly she stood And on the sudden dropped.
column2: She stood tremblingly and suddenly dropped.

column1: But what a fool am I to chat with you, When I should bid good morrow to my bride And seal the title with a lovely kiss!
column2: But what a fool I am to chat with you when I should give my bride a good morning and seal the title with a lovely kiss!

column1: To none but thee, no more but when to thee.
column2: No more than you, no more than when you’re coming.

column1: Come on, i' God’s name, once more toward our father’s.
column2: Come on, God’s name, and go back to our father’s house.

column1: Can any of your neighbors tell, Kate?
column2: Can any of your neighbors tell you, Kate?

column1: Come, Casca, you and I will yet ere day See Brutus at his house.
column2: Come on, Casca, you and I will see Brutus at his house on the day.

column1: She will indite him to some supper.
column2: She’ll indite him to some supper.

column1: Faith, like enough.
column2: Yes, that’s enough.

column1: No, my lord, not I. Alas, it is the baseness of thy fear That makes thee strangle thy propriety.
column2: No, my lord, not me.

column1: O Antony!
column2: Oh, Antony!

column1: You shall be more beloving than beloved.
column2: You’ll be more beloving than you’ll be beloved.

column1: What, a feast, a feast?
column2: What, a feast, a feast?

column1: She soon shall know of us, by some of ours, How honorable and how kindly we Determine for her, for Caesar cannot live To be ungentle.
column2: She will know soon, by some of ours, how honorable and kindly we are determined for her, because Caesar cannot live to be ungtle.

column1: Do you sing it, and I’ll dance it.
column2: Do you sing it, and I’ll dance it.

column1: I think so too.
column2: I think so too.

column1: Therefore all hearts in love use their own tongues.
column2: Therefore, all lovers use their own tongues.

column1: If it be that— If it be that, or any that was hers, It speaks against her with the other proofs.

column1: Were not you even now with the Countess Olivia?

column2: I’m arresting you for high treason, by the name of Thomas Grey, knight, of Northumberland.

column1: Not I.

column1: It was he That made the overture of thy treasons to us, Who is too good to pity thee.

column1: Nothing certainer.

column1: I take no pleasure In aught an eunuch has.

column2: Even if it’s honest, it’s never good to bring bad news.

column1: A very gentle beast, of a good conscience.
column2: A very gentle beast, with a good conscience.

column1: I afeard of him!
column2: I’ve scolded him!

column1: I wish your Worship well.
column2: I wish you well.

column1: Those that have known the earth so full of faults.
column2: The people who have known the earth so full of faults.

column1: Intend a kind of zeal both to the Prince and Claudio, as in love of your brother’s honor, who hath made this match, and his friend’s reputation, who is thus like to be cozened with the semblance of a maid, that you have discovered thus.
column2: Give the Prince and Claudio a kind of zeal, as in love with your brother’s honor, who made this match, and his friend’s reputation, who is like a semblance of a mai

column1: It sounds no more, and sure, it waits upon Some god o' th' island.
column2: It’s not a more sane thing, and it’s sure it’s waiting on some god on the island.

column1: You’ve said, sir.
column2: You’ve said what you’re saying, sir.

column1: Farewell, for I must leave you.
column2: Farewell, because I have to leave you.

column1: Back you shall not to the house, unless you undertake that with me which with as much safety you might answer him.
column2: You can’t go back to the house unless you’re able to do something with me, which you can do with as much security as you can.

column1: A good direction, warlike sovereign.
column2: A good direction, warlike sovereign.

column1: And joy comes well in such a needy time.
column2: And joy comes well in such a difficult time.

column1: What wouldst thou now?
column2: What do you want now?

column1: Hearty thanks.
column2: Thank you very much.

column1: Is it so brave a lass?
column2: Is it so brave?

column1: Tis noble Kent, your friend.
column2: It’s noble Kent, your friend.

column1: My brave spirit!
column2: My brave spirit!

column1: Your Majesty says very true.
column2: Your Majesty is very true.

column1: Let fall thy blade on vulnerable crests; I bear a charmèd life, which must not yield To one of woman born.
column2: Let your blade fall on vulnerable crests.

column1: I know your favor well, Though now you have no sea-cap on your head.— Take him away.
column2: I know your favor well, even if you have no seacap on your head.—Take him away.

column1: It ish give over.
column2: It’s going to give over.

column1: For Falstaff, he is dead, and we must earn therefore.
column2: Falstaff, he’s dead, and we have to earn it.

column1: Our power is ready; Our lack is nothing but our leave.
column2: Our power is ready; our lack is nothing but our leave.

column1: There’s few or none will entertain it.
column2: There are few or none of them who will entertain it.

column1: Said you so?
column2: Did you say that?

column1: Then one of you will prove a shrunk panel and, like green timber, warp, warp.
column2: Then one of you will be a shrunk panel and, like green timber, warp, warp.

column1: Indeed, he is so.
column2: Yes, he is.

column1: Come, warble, come.
column2: Come, warble, come.

column1: But wherefore, villain, didst thou kill my cousin?
column2: But why did you kill my cousin?

column1: Oh, yes, I heard them all, and more too, for some of them had in them more feet than the verses would bear.
column2: Oh yes, I heard them all, and more, because some of them had more feet in them than the verses would bear.

column1: Kent, on thy life, no more.
column2: Kent, on your life, don’t worry.

column1: A plague o' both your houses!
column2: A plague kills both your houses!

column1: By heaven, I charge thee, speak.
column2: I swear, by heaven, I’ll tell you.

column1: I thank God, I thank God!
column2: Thank God, thank God!

column1: Do so.
column2: Do so.

column1: Good Portia, go to bed.
column2: Good Portia, go to bed.

column1: To England will I steal, and there I’ll steal.
column2: I’ll go to England, and I’ll go there.

column1: And I.
column2: And I.

column1: And ever will—though he do shake me off To beggarly divorcement—love him dearly, Comfort forswear me!
column2: And if he shakes me off to beg me to divorce me, I’ll always love him.

column1: Oh, fie, fie, fie!
column2: Oh, oh, oh, oh, oh!

column1: Approach and speak.
column2: Come and speak.

column1: Oh, but she’ll keep her word.
column2: Oh, but she’ll keep her word.

column1: Nor for yours neither.
column2: And you can’t do it for you.

column1: And, hark!
column2: Listen!

column1: Yea, Richard, when I know, for I protest As yet I do not.
column2: Yes, Richard, when I know, because I’m not protesting yet.

column1: Oh, yet I do repent me of my fury, That I did kill them.
column2: Oh, but I’m sorry I killed them.

column1: Sir, here’s the door.
column2: Here’s the door, sir.

column1: I dreamt there was an emperor Antony.
column2: I dreamed there was an emperor Antony.

column1: Let me ask you one word in private.
column2: Let me ask you one word in private.

column1: Now they believe it and withal whet me To be revenged on Rivers, Dorset, Grey; But then I sigh and, with a piece of scripture, Tell them that God bids us do good for evil; And thus I clothe my naked villainy With odd old ends stolen out of Holy Writ, And seem a saint when most I play the devil.
column2: Now they believe it and whet me to be revenged on Rivers, Dorset, Grey.

column1: Think you so?
column2: Do you think so?

column1: Come on and kiss me, Kate.
column2: Come on and kiss me, Kate.

column1: Hob, nob, is his word.
column2: Hob, nob, is his word.

column1: What dost thou with thy best apparel on?
column2: What are you wearing your best clothes?

column1: If she convey Letters to Richmond, you shall answer it.
column2: If she sends letters to Richmond, you’ll answer it.

column1: Be it so, Lysander.
column2: Be it, Lysander.

column1: We’ll so begin these rites As we do trust they’ll end, in true delights.
column2: We’ll begin these rituals as soon as we trust them to end, in true delights.

column1: Good morrow, Catesby.— You may jest on, but, by the Holy Rood, I do not like these several councils, I.
column2: Good morning, Catesby.—You can’t go on, but I don’t like these several councils, I swear.

column1: Remember our reward when the deed’s done.
column2: Remember our reward when the deed’s done.

column1: I find it still, when I have leave to sleep.
column2: I find it still, when I’m awake.

column1: If such a one be fit to govern, speak.
column2: If such a person is right to govern, speak.

column1: I will not swear these are my hands.
column2: I won’t swear that these are my hands.

column1: He is of note.
column2: He’s very important.

column1: Thou art a villain to impeach me thus.
column2: You’re a villain to impeach me like this.

column1: I, sir, am Dromio.
column2: I, sir, am Dromio.

column1: Talk not to me, for I’ll not speak a word.
column2: Don’t talk to me, because I won’t say a word.

column1: I can hardly forbear hurling things at him.
column2: I can’t resist throwing things at him.

column1: They would be better if well followed.
column2: They would be better if they were followed.

column1: Ay, or drinking, fencing, swearing, Quarreling, drabbing—you may go so far.
column2: Yes, or drinking, fencing, swearing, arguing, drabbing—you can go so far.

column1: Tis evermore the prologue to his sleep.
column2: He’s always a prologue to sleep.

column1: Sir, I lack advancement.
column2: Sir, I’m not getting any progress.

column1: Help to dress me, good coz, good Meg, good Ursula.
column2: Help me dress up, good coz, good Meg, good Ursula.

column1: Be of good cheer, youth.
column2: Be cheerful, young man.

column1: Ay, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads.
column2: Yes, the heads of the maids, or their maidenheads.

column1: And leave us, Publius, lest that the people, Rushing on us, should do your age some mischief.
column2: And leave us, Publius, so that the people who rush on us should do some mischief in your age.

column1: Let Lucius and Titinius guard our door.
column2: Let Lucius and Titinius guard our door.

column1: Had it th' ability of life to thank you.
column2: If you could thank you, you would have a good life.

column1: Tis wonderful.
column2: It’s wonderful.

column1: Madam, I had rather seal my lips Than to my peril speak that which is not.
column2: Madam, I’d rather seal my lips than speak to my own danger.

column1: If it be thus to dream, still let me sleep!
column2: If it’s like dreaming, let me sleep!

column1: I am none of his flirt-gills.
column2: I’m not one of his flirty gills.

column1: My lord?
column2: My lord?

column1: If he were dead, what would betide on me?
column2: If he were dead, what would be the odds on me?

column1: What are you?
column2: Who are you?

column1: You think none but your sheets are privy to your wishes.
column2: You think nothing but your sheets are suited to your wishes.

column1: If I do live, I will be good to thee.
column2: If I live, I’ll be good to you.

column1: If we do lose this battle, then is this The very last time we shall speak together.
column2: If we lose this battle, then this is the last time we’ll speak together.

column1: Let her hang me.
column2: Let her hang me.

column1: But if you fail, without more speech, my lord, You must be gone from hence immediately.
column2: But if you fail, you have to go away immediately, my lord.

column1: Tell me that.
column2: Tell me that.

column1: Oh, villain!
column2: Oh, villain!

column1: Save means to live.
column2: Save the means to live.

column1: Shall we not?
column2: Shall we?

column1: The earth, that’s nature’s mother, is her tomb.
column2: The earth, that’s nature’s mother, is her tomb.

column1: So hath my lord dared him to single fight.
column2: So my lord has urged him to fight single.

column1: Back do I toss these treasons to thy head, With the hell-hated lie o'erwhelm thy heart—
column2: I’ll throw these treasons back to your head with the hell-hated lie that’s causing your heart to fall asleep—

column1: Then God be blessed, it is the blessèd sun.
column2: Then God be blessed, it’s the blessed sun.

column1: Bid her come hither.
column2: Tell her to come here.

column1: Then walk we forth, even to the marketplace, And waving our red weapons o'er our heads Let’s all cry, “Peace, freedom, and liberty!” Stoop, then, and wash.
column2: Then we’ll walk out to the marketplace, and waving our red weapons over our heads, let’s all cry, “Peace, freedom, and liberty!” Stoop, then, and wash.

column1: Tis marvel, but that you are but newly come, You might have heard it else proclaimed about.
column2: It’s marvellous, but you’re only coming soon, you might have heard it else.

column1: Mine eyes did sicken at the sight and could not Endure a further view.
column2: I couldn’t see any further.

column1: Close by, my master.
column2: Close by, my master.

column1: Conceit upon her father.
column2: Ask her father.

column1: Did he confess it?
column2: Did he confess?

column2: But now, Baptista, I’ll go to your younger daughter.

column1: Do they hold the same estimation they did when I was in the city?
column2: Do they think they did the same thing when I was in the city?

column1: What proof shall I make of that?
column2: What do I need to do about that?

column1: I cannot live to hear the news from England.
column2: I can’t live to hear the news from England.

column1: Now, in good sadness, son Petruchio, I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.
column2: Now, in good sadness, son Petruchio, I think you have the shrewdest of all.

column1: We have, sir.
column2: We have, sir.

column1: Tis now near night.
column2: It’s near night.

column1: I fear it, I promise you.
column2: I’m afraid, I promise you.

column2: I have no wit, no words, no worth, no action, no speech, no power to stir men’s blood.

column2: Ophelia, walk here.

column2: Don’t you see that I’m out of breath?

column2: How low am I, you painted a maypole?

column1: I am ready.
column2: I’m ready.

column2: Please, who are you talking about?

column1: If she sustain him and his hundred knights When I have showed th' unfitness— Here, madam.
column2: If she supports him and his hundred knights when I show you aren’t fit— Here, madam.

column1: As sweet as balm, as soft as air, as gentle— O Antony!—Nay, I will take thee too.
column2: As sweet as balm, as soft as air, as gentle— Oh Antony!—No, I’ll take you too.

column2: Well too.

column2: We’ll feast each other if we’re parting, and let’s draw lots of people who will start.

column2: Think, my lord?

column1: Well, I will be so much a sinner, to be a double-dealer.
column2: Well, I’ll be a sinner, to be a double-dealer.

column2: Reproach and everlasting shame sits in our bushes.

column2: You’ve said what you’re saying now.

column2: Oh, the woman who could have killed you by strangling you in her womb, from all the slaughters you’ve done, you’ve done.

column1: Unless the master were the man.
column2: Unless the master were the man.

column1: Ay, marry, are they, sir.
column2: Yes, they are, sir.

column1: Oh, that she knew she were!
column2: Oh, she knew she were!

column1: Madam, good hope.
column2: Madam, good hope.

column1: We shall be the more marketable.—Bonjour, Monsieur Le Beau.
column2: We’ll be the more attractive.—Bonjour, Monsieur Le Beau.

column1: So should we you, if you should be our king.
column2: We should, if you were our king, do so.

column2: Please, chuck, come here.

column1: I feel this pinprick.
column2: I feel this pinprick.

column1: Poor souls, they perished.

column2: If you’re false, you’ll hang alive on the next tree until the famine clings to you.

column2: Isn’t that blood as modest as it is to witness simple virtue?

column1: Thou hast hit it.
column2: You’ve hit it.

column1: As I descended?
column2: As I walked down?

column1: Very well.
column2: Very well.

column2: Listen.

column2: How can this be?

column2: It’s not appropriate to obey him like that.

column2: Who doesn’t know that the gentle duke is dead?

column2: The sound of lovers’ tongues by night is silver-sweet, like the softest music to listen to!

column2: You’re in the land, indeed, and you’re letting me know of my father’s house, but since the cuckoo doesn’t build for himself, you can stay in the land as you can.

column2: The prayers of holy saints and wronged souls, like high-recommended bulwarks, stand before our faces.

column1: Content.
column2: Content.

column1: Here at your service.
column2: Here at your service.

column1: Tis a point of wisdom.
column2: It’s a good idea to think about it.

column2: Then let the trumpets sound the tucket sonance and the note to mount, because our approach will so dare the field that England will be afraid and yield.

column1: We found him in the churchyard.
column2: We found him in the churchyard.

column1: Will either of you bear me a challenge to him?
column2: Will either of you challenge him?

column1: He dreams.
column2: He’s dreaming.

column1: Here they’ll be, man.
column2: Here they’ll be, man.

column1: Very brief, and to exceeding good sense—less.
column2: Very brief, and to exceeding good sense—less.

column1: Who chooseth me shall have as much as he deserves”!
column2: Who chooses me will have as much as he deserves”!

column2: What’s going on, Tubal?

column1: He shall see none to fear.
column2: He won’t see any fear.

column1: Wherefore’s this noise?
column2: Why are you making this noise?

column1: Our duty to your honor.
column2: We’re your duty.

column1: Tybalt is gone, and Romeo banishèd.
column2: Tybalt is gone, and Romeo has been banned.

column2: Sir, my liege, don’t attack your mind with beating on the strangeness of this business.

column1: Fear it, my dear sister, And keep you in the rear of your affection, Out of the shot and danger of desire.
column2: Fear it, my dear sister, and keep you in the rear of your affection, out of the shot and the danger of desire.

column1: Change you color?
column2: Do you change your color?

column1: For the poor wren, The most diminutive of birds, will fight, Her young ones in her nest, against the owl.
column2: The poor wren, the most swollen of birds, will fight against the owl, her young ones in her nest.

column1: I am not mad.
column2: I’m not insane.

column1: I am sorry I beat thee.
column2: I’m sorry I beat you.

column1: I have heard of some kind of men that put quarrels purposely on others, to taste their valor.
column2: I’ve heard of some kind of men who put quarrels on others to taste their valor.

column1: Faith, I know not what to say.
column2: I don’t know what to say.

column1: Why, but there’s many a man hath more hair than wit.
column2: But many men have more hair than wit.

column1: Abhorred villain!
column2: Abhorred villain!

column1: And how does your content Tender your own good fortune?
column2: And how do you feel about your own good fortune?

column1: Ha!
column2: Ha!

column1: Good night.
column2: Good night.

column1: Or would you have me speak after my custom, as being a professed tyrant to their sex?
column2: Or would you want me to speak like a tyrant to their sex?

column1: Our duties, and the pledge.
column2: We’re doing our duties, and we’re giving them the pledge.

column1: The excuse that thou dost make in this delay Is longer than the tale thou dost excuse.
column2: The excuse you make for this delay is longer than the story you’re telling.

column1: Why, sir, a carpenter.
column2: You’re a carpenter, sir.

column1: What life is in that to be the death of this marriage?
column2: What life does that mean to be the death of this marriage?

column1: His glory not extenuated wherein he was worthy, nor his offenses enforced for which he suffered death.
column2: His glory wasn’t attenuated when he was worthy, nor his crimes for which he died.

column1: Within my tent his bones tonight shall lie Most like a soldier, ordered honorably.
column2: I’ll lay his bones in my tent tonight, like a soldier, or ordered honorably.

column1: Hast thou no letters to me from the friar?
column2: Don’t you have any letters from the friar to me?

column1: This is as strange a maze as e'er men trod, And there is in this business more than nature Was ever conduct of.
column2: This is as strange a maze as a gang of men, and there is more in this business than nature ever did.

column1: Father, and wife, and gentlemen, adieu.
column2: Father, wife, and gentlemen, adieu.

column1: Thou seest the world, Volumnius, how it goes.
column2: You’re spotting the world, Volumnius, how it goes.

column1: Come, go we to the king.
column2: Come on, we’ll go to the king.

column1: Ye gods, it doth amaze me A man of such a feeble temper should So get the start of the majestic world And bear the palm alone.
column2: Yes, gods, it amazes me that a man with such a poor temper should start the majestic world and bear the palm alone.

column1: O earth, which this blood drink’st revenge his death!
column2: Oh, earth, which this blood drink revenges his death!

column1: Therefore thy earliness doth me assure Thou art uproused by some distemperature.
column2: So I assure you’re a bit sane.

column1: What, have you dined at home?
column2: Have you eaten at home?

column1: Flower of this purple dye, Hit with Cupid’s archery, Sink in apple of his eye.
column2: The purple flower, hit with Cupid’s archery, sinks in the apple of his eye.

column1: I cannot speak your England.
column2: I can’t speak your England.

column1: I' th' air or th' earth?
column2: Is it in the air or the earth?

column1: A traveler.
column2: A traveler.

column1: Oh, how I long to have some chat with her!
column2: Oh, how long I’ve been to chat with her!

column1: I have it, Tranio!
column2: I have it, Tranio!

column1: Adieu.
column2: Goodbye.

column1: There is no love in you.
column2: You don’t have any love.

column1: Let her know ’t.—  And he will fill thy wishes to the brim With principalities.
column2: Tell her.—And he’ll fill your wishes with a lot of sanity.

column1: I will none of your money.
column2: I won’t spend any of your money.

column1: Lovers can see to do their amorous rites By their own beauties, or, if love be blind, It best agrees with night.
column2: Lovers can see that they’re doing their rites by their own beauties, or if love is blind, it’s best to agree with night.

column1: What villains have done this?
column2: What villains have done this?

column1: Now art thou Romeo.
column2: Now you’re Romeo.

column1: If thou beest not immortal, look about you.
column2: If you’re not immortal, look at you.

column1: I arrest thee of high treason, by the name of Richard, Earl of Cambridge.
column2: I’m arresting you for high treason, by the name of Richard, Earl of Cambridge.

column1: Lucius!—Fast asleep?
column2: Lucius!—Fast asleep?

column1: For when mine hours Were nice and lucky, men did ransom lives Of me for jests; but now I’ll set my teeth And send to darkness all that stop me.
column2: When my hours were nice and lucky, men ransom me for stealing my money, but now I’ll put my teeth on and send all the things that stop me.

column1: Good your highness, patience.
column2: Good your highness, patience.

column1: As much to him, else is his thanks too much.
column2: As much to him as I do, and his thanks are too much.

column1: Eight score eight hours?
column2: Eight score eight hours?

column1: That’s my brave lord!
column2: That’s my brave lord!

column1: Was this fair paper, this most goodly book, Made to write “whore” upon?
column2: Was this fair paper, this very good book, made to write “whore”?

column1: Alas, why gnaw you so your nether lip?
column2: Why are you so gnawing?

column1: Kneel not, gentle Portia.
column2: Don’t scold me, Portia.

column1: They did, Fluellen.
column2: They did, Fluellen.

column1: Nor would we deign him burial of his men Till he disbursed at Saint Colme’s Inch Ten thousand dollars to our general use.
column2: We wouldn’t deign him until he was buried at Saint Colme’s Inch for ten thousand dollars.

column1: O lamentable day!
column2: Oh, sad day!

column1: How does my old acquaintance of this isle?— Honey, you shall be well desired in Cyprus, I have found great love amongst them.
column2: How did my old acquaintance of this island be?—House, you’ll be well desired in Cyprus, I have found great love among them.

column1: Let not the Nurse lie with thee in thy chamber.
column2: Don’t let the Nurse lie with you in your room.

column1: Let them come before Master Constable.
column2: Let them come before Master Constable.

column1: Most mighty duke, vouchsafe me speak a word.
column2: Most mighty duke, please tell me to speak a word.

column1: In time we hate that which we often fear.
column2: We hate things that we often fear.

column1: Come, come, away.
column2: Come, come, go away.

column1: As sure, my liege, as I do see your Grace.
column2: As sure, my liege, as I see your Grace.

column1: Because I would not see thy cruèl nails Pluck out his poor old eyes, nor thy fierce sister In his anointed flesh stick boarish fangs.
column2: Because I wouldn’t see your cruèl nails pluck out his poor old eyes, and your fierce sister would stick boarish fangs in his anointed flesh.

column1: Here, my good lord.
column2: Here, my good lord.

column1: This is a fellow of the selfsame color Our sister speaks of.—Come, bring away the stocks!
column2: This is a fellow of the same color that our sister speaks of.—Come, bring away the stocks!

column1: And we’ll consign thereto.—Will you, fair sister, Go with the princes or stay here with us?
column2: And we’ll ship there.—Would you, fair sister, go with the princes or stay here with us?

column1: Leave him to my displeasure.—Edmund, keep you our sister company.

column1: My lord is often thus And hath been from his youth.
column2: My lord is often so, and he’s been from his youth.

column1: Thou shalt not from this grove Till I torment thee for this injury.— My gentle Puck, come hither.

column1: I shall miss thee, But yet thou shalt have freedom.—So, so, so.— To the king’s ship, invisible as thou art.
column2: I’ll miss you, but you’ll have freedom.—So, so, so.—To the king’s ship, invisible as you are.

column1: First, if all obstacles were cut away And that my path were even to the crown As the ripe revenue and due of birth, Yet so much is my poverty of spirit, So mighty and so many my defects, That I would rather hide me from my greatness, Being a bark to brook no mighty sea, Than in my greatness covet to be hid And in the vapor of my glory smothered.
column2: First, if all obstacles were cut away and my path would be to the crown as the ripe income and due of birth, so much is my lack of spirit, so powerful and so many my defects, that I would rather hide

column1: Here is yet a postscript.
column2: Here’s a postscript.

column1: Monday, my lord.
column2: Monday, my lord.

column1: Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.
column2: Fair Beatrice, thank you for your efforts.

column1: But do you hear, sir, have you married my daughter without asking my goodwill?
column2: But do you hear that you’ve married my daughter without asking my goodwill?

column1: And shall I couple hell?
column2: And should I just marry hell?

column1: Cursed be thy stones for thus deceiving me!
column2: Cursed to be your stones for deceiving me like this!

column2: What then?

column1: Ay, mistress, and Petruchio is the master, That teacheth tricks eleven and twenty long To tame a shrew and charm her chattering tongue.
column2: Yes, mistress, and Petruchio is the master, who has taught you eleven and twenty tricks to tame a shrew and charm her chattering tongue.

column1: Roderigo!
column2: Roderigo!

column1: Bid me tear the bond.
column2: Tell me to tear the bond.

column1: The readiest way to make the wench amends Is to become her husband and her father; The which will I, not all so much for love As for another secret close intent By marrying her which I must reach unto.
column2: The best way to make the wench amends is to become her husband and her father.

column1: I know she is an irksome brawling scold.
column2: I know she’s a scolding.

column1: This deed will be well welcome to Lorenzo.

column1: Her husband, knave.

column1: O woeful, woeful, woeful day!

column1: Enjoy thy plainness.
column2: Enjoy your plainness.

column1: And so it is, truly, and very notably discharged.
column2: That’s true, and it’s very well discharged.

column2: He’s a coward and a coistrel who won’t drink to my niece until his brains turn toe like a parish top.

column2: I know you’re my eldest brother, and you’d be able to know me in the gentle condition of blood.
