column1: Spare not for the cost.
column2: Don’t worry about the cost.

column1: In faith, she’s too curst.
column2: She’s too scolded.

column1: Let wantons light of heart Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels.
column2: Let the sane rushes get a little sane.

column1: Doth not the day break here?
column2: Don’t you break the day here?

column1: Oh, let us hence.
column2: Let’s go.

column1: Where the devil should he learn our language?
column2: Where the devil should he learn our language?

column1: Before my body I throw my warlike shield.
column2: I’ll throw my shield before my body is thrown.

column1: Ay.
column2: Yes.

column1: Jailer, look to him.
column2: Jailer, look at him.

column1: My lord, I do not know that I did cry.
column2: My lord, I don’t know that I cried.

column1: Be pleased to tell us— For this is from the present—how you take The offers we have sent you.
column2: Please tell us how we’ve sent you the offers.

column1: Hold little faith, though thou hast too much fear.
column2: Don’t be afraid, even if you’re afraid.

column1: I am no fee’d post, lady.
column2: I’m not a fee-free person, lady.

column1: I do not set my life in a pin’s fee, And for my soul—what can it do to that, Being a thing immortal as itself?
column2: I don’t set my life in a pin’s fee, and for my soul—what can it do to that, being as immortal as itself?

column1: Who calls so loud?
column2: Who’s calling so loud?

column1: Due for a chain your husband had of him.
column2: You’re due for a necklace your husband had with him.

column1: Here’s to Caesar.
column2: Here’s to Caesar.

column1: Prithee, if thou lovest me, tell me.
column2: Please tell me if you love me.

column1: His royal grace, Whom God preserve better than you would wish, Cannot be quiet scarce a breathing while But you must trouble him with lewd complaints.
column2: His royal grace, who is better preserved than you would wish, can’t be quiet and quiet, but you have to trouble him with a few lewd complaints.

column1: God and our innocence defend and guard us!
column2: God and our innocence protect and protect us!

column1: But ere they came,–O, let me say no more!
column2: But they came, let me say no more!

column1: Find out this villain, Edmund.
column2: Find out this villain, Edmund.

column1: Are our eyes our own?
column2: Are our eyes our own?

column1: Know we this face or no?
column2: Do we know this face or not?

column1: What, are the brothers parted?
column2: What, are the brothers separated?

column1: This is the very false gallop of verses.
column2: This is the false saga of verses.

column1: Now I’ll tell you without asking.
column2: Now I’ll tell you without asking.

column1: Not a soul But felt a fever of the mad and played Some tricks of desperation.
column2: Not a soul but a man felt a fever of the madness and played some tricks of desperation.

column1: I am sped.
column2: I’m sped.

column1: Do you not see that I am out of breath?
column2: Don’t you see that I’m out of breath?

column1: Monstrous!
column2: Monstrous!

column1: What is your name?
column2: What’s your name?

column1: After a little time, I’ll beat him too.
column2: After a little time, I’ll beat him too.

column1: Speak but one rhyme, and I am satisfied.
column2: Speak one rhyme, and I’m satisfied.

column1: O rude unthankfulness!
column2: Oh, rude unthankfulness!

column1: I chose her when I could not ask my father For his advice, nor thought I had one.
column2: I chose her when I couldn’t ask my father for his advice, and I didn’t think I had one.

column1: If this be not that you look for, I have no more to say, But bid Bianca farewell forever and a day.
column2: If this is not what you’re looking for, I’ll tell you nothing more, but please, Bianca, goodbye forever and a day.

column1: In the meantime I will draw a bill of properties such as our play wants.
column2: In the meantime, I’ll draw a list of properties that we want to play.

column1: My lord, the roinish clown, at whom so oft Your Grace was wont to laugh, is also missing.
column2: My lord, the roinish clown, at whom you were so often tempted to laugh, is also missing.

column1: Fathers that wear rags  Do make their children blind.
column2: Fathers who wear rags make their children blind.

column1: If this be so, why blame you me to love you?
column2: If that’s true, why do you blame me for love you?

column1: Now, most noble Brutus, The gods today stand friendly that we may, Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age.
column2: Now, most noble Brutus, the gods are friendly so that we can lead our loyal servants to age.

column1: Fie, what a question’s that If thou wert near a lewd interpreter!
column2: What a question you’re asking if you’re near a lewd interpreter!

column1: Thou canst not frown, thou canst not look askance, Nor bite the lip as angry wenches will, Nor hast thou pleasure to be cross in talk.
column2: You can’t frown, you can’t look a bit sane, or bite the lip as angry wenches will, or you’re not willing to be cross in talk.

column1: I pray you tell your brother how well I counterfeited.
column2: Please tell your brother how well I’ve faked.

column1: I know his trumpet.
column2: I know his trumpet.

column1: Nor I, my lord, in faith.
column2: I’m not, my lord.

column1: Peace!
column2: Quiet!

column1: Let’s see.
column2: Let’s see.

column1: Niece, will you look to those things I told you of?
column2: Niece, will you look at what I told you about?

column1: Write to me very shortly, And you shall understand from me her mind.
column2: Write to me very soon, and you’ll understand her thoughts from me.

column1: Speak you so gently?
column2: Do you speak so gently?

column1: But do not look for further recompense Than thine own gladness that thou art employed.
column2: But don’t look for more compensation than your own happiness.

column1: Take it in what sense thou wilt.
column2: Take it in what sense you want.

column1: I do not like her name.
column2: I don’t like her name.

column1: At your choice, sir.
column2: At your choice, sir.

column1: Why, I am sorry for thee, gentle Silvius.
column2: I’m sorry for you, gentle Silvius.

column1: The age is grown so picked that the toe of the peasant comes so near the heel of the courtier he galls his kibe.—How long hast thou been a grave-maker?
column2: The age has grown so quickly that the toe of the peasant comes so near the heel of the courtier he galles his kibe.—How long have you been a gravemaker?

column1: Good sir, be a man, Think every bearded fellow that’s but yoked May draw with you.
column2: Good sir, be a man, think every bearded fellow who’s only yoked may draw with you.

column1: What do they in the north When they should serve their sovereign in the west?
column2: What do they do in the north when they should serve their sovereign in the west?

column1: Come in, tailor.
column2: Come in, tailor.

column1: What will you do?
column2: What are you going to do?

column1: So, I am satisfied.
column2: So, I’m satisfied.

column1: Good gentle youth, tempt not a desperate man.
column2: Good gentle young man, don’t tempt a desperate man.

column1: What, drawn, and talk of peace?
column2: What, drawn, and talk about peace?

column1: Thou hast quarreled with a man for coughing in the street because he hath wakened thy dog that hath lain asleep in the sun.
column2: You have fought with a man for coughing in the street because he woke up your dog who slept in the sun.

column1: I guess at it.
column2: I guess at it.

column1: I tell thee true.
column2: I’m telling you that.

column1: What meanest thou by that, Malvolio?
column2: What do you mean by that, Malvolio?

column1: Did he ask for me?
column2: Did he ask for me?

column1: Bear me, good friends, where Cleopatra bides.
column2: Bear me, good friends, where Cleopatra is.

column1: Why, what did I?
column2: What did I do?

column1: I would not have such a heart in my bosom for the dignity of the whole body.
column2: I wouldn’t have a heart like this in my heart for the dignity of the whole body.

column1: I had a pass with him, rapier, scabbard, and all, and he gives me the stuck-in with such a mortal motion, that it is inevitable.
column2: I had a pass with him, rapier, scabbard, and all, and he gives me the slapstick with such a mortal motion that it’s inevitable.

column1: By my troth, my lord, I cannot tell what to think of it, but that she loves him with an enraged affection, it is past the infinite of thought.
column2: I can’t tell you what to think of it, my lord, but she loves him with a raged affection, and it’s beyond the infinite of thought.

column1: Here, master.
column2: Here, master.

column1: I must leave you.
column2: I have to leave you.

column1: Lady, were you her bedfellow last night?
column2: Lady, were you asleep last night?

column1: The spring, the head, the fountain of your blood Is stopped; the very source of it is stopped.
column2: The spring, the head, the fountain of your blood is stopped.

column1: So may you lose your arms.
column2: You may lose your arms.

column1: I’ll ride your horse as well as I ride you.
column2: I’ll ride your horse as well as I ride you.

column1: I serve as good a man as you.
column2: I’m as good a man as you are.

column1: What dost thou mean?
column2: What do you mean?

column1: Do you intend to stay with me tonight?
column2: Do you intend to stay with me tonight?

column1: I do fear, the people Choose Caesar for their king.
column2: I’m afraid the people choose Caesar for their king.

column1: I am too sore enpiercèd with his shaft To soar with his light feathers, and so bound, I cannot bound a pitch above dull woe.
column2: I’m too sore enpiercé with his shaft to soar with his light feathers, and I can’t get a pitch above dull sorrow.

column1: Is it possible that any villainy should be so dear?
column2: Is it possible that any villainy is so dear?

column1: Come, gentlemen, Let us consult upon tomorrow’s business Into my tent.
column2: Come, gentlemen, let’s go to my tent to discuss the business of tomorrow.

column1: Good, i' faith.
column2: Good, I’m sure.

column1: Well then, if ever I thank any man, I’ll thank you.
column2: Well then, if I ever thank any man, I’ll thank you.

column1: What’s thy pleasure?
column2: What’s your pleasure?

column1: Make the trial of it in any constant question.
column2: Make sure you’re in a constant battle.

column1: Nothing at all.
column2: Nothing at all.

column1: I do I know not what and fear to find Mine eye too great a flatterer for my mind.
column2: I don’t know what I’m thinking, and I’m afraid to find my eye too flattering for me.

column1: Oh, she knew well Thy love did read by rote, that could not spell.
column2: Oh, she knew well that your love was written by a man who couldn’t spell it.

column1: No.
column2: No.

column2: Benvolio, who started this bloody fight?

column1: An unauthorized kiss!
column2: An illegal kiss!

column1: But let us rear The higher our opinion, that our stirring Can from the lap of Egypt’s widow pluck The ne’er lust-wearied Antony.
column2: But let’s get the higher our opinion, that our lust-wearing lord can pluck Antony from the lap of the Egyptian widow.

column1: Look, here comes a lover of mine and a lover of hers.
column2: Look, here comes a lover of mine and a lover of hers.

column1: If ’twere no other— 'Tis but so, I warrant.
column2: If it weren’t the other— it’s just that, I’m sure.

column2: One of you, Kate, you must kiss and be familiar with.—Where are my slippers?

column1: Yes, madam.
column2: Yes, madam.

column1: If their purgation did consist in words, They are as innocent as grace itself.
column2: If they were merely a word, they would be as innocent as the grace itself.

column1: I dare swear he is no hypocrite but prays from his heart.
column2: I swear he’s not a hypocrite, but I’m praying from his heart.

column2: It’s a wise father who knows his own child.

column2: Here, here I’ll remain with worms that are your chambermaids.

column2: I’ll get some flax and whites of eggs to apply to his bleeding face.

column1: O, sir, the conceit is deeper than you think for.
column2: Oh, sir, the conceit is deeper than you think.

column1: If ever I return to you again, I’ll bring you comfort.
column2: If I ever return to you again, I’ll bring you comfort.

column1: Ah, Rosencrantz!
column2: Ah, Rosencrantz!

column1: What’s this?
column2: What’s this?

column2: No, but he prated and spoke such scurvy and provoking terms against your honor that, with the little godliness I have, I had to forbear him.

column1: Oh, who hath done this deed?
column2: Who did this deed?

column1: Fire!
column2: Fire!

column1: He dares not come there for the candle.

column2: What’s going on, sir!

column1: Not a dump, we.
column2: Not a dump, we’re not.

column1: The law that threatened death becomes thy friend And turns it to exile—there art thou happy.
column2: The law that threatened death becomes your friend and turns it into exile—there are you happy.

column1: And all my children?
column2: And all my children?

column1: Well, I am glad that all things sort so well.
column2: Well, I’m glad everything works out so well.

column1: Think you but that I know our state secure, I would be so triumphant as I am?
column2: Isn’t that you think I’m a good man, but I know that our state is secure, I’d be as triumphant as I am?

column2: Why, Dromio?

column1: Good night, good night!
column2: Good night, good night!

column2: Then, window, let day in and let life go.

column2: But who is he?

column2: The desperate weather has banged the Turks so much that their plans are halting.

column1: It hath made me mad.

column1: My lord?
column2: My lord?

column1: Take up her bed And bear her women from the monument.
column2: Take up her bed and bear her women from the monument.

column2: If there were twenty of the greatest tributaries who acknowledge Caesar, would I find them so sour with the hand of her here—what’s her name since she was Cleopatra?

column1: You shall find me apt enough to that, sir, an you will give me occasion.
column2: You’ll find me apt enough to do that, sir, so you can give me some opportunity.

column1: You see how simple and how fond I am.
column2: You see how simple and fond I am.

column2: Well, Syracusian, tell us in brief the reason why you dep-arted from your native home and for what reason you came to Ephesus.

column1: For certain she is dead, and by strange manner.
column2: She’s certainly dead, and she’s strangely dressed.

column1: There, take you that, sir knave.
column2: Take that, sir knave.

column2: Don’t be disciplined, don’t delay, because tomorrow is a busy day, my lords.

column1: Tis very like.
column2: It’s very similar.

column1: Men’s eyes were made to look and let them gaze.
column2: Men’s eyes were made to look and let them see.

column2: I swear it’s better to be abused than to just know a little.

column1: I do not know you so good a man as myself.
column2: I don’t know you’re as good a man as myself.

column1: Eternity was in our lips and eyes, Bliss in our brows’ bent, none our parts so poor But was a race of heaven.
column2: Eternity was in our lips and eyes, a bliss in our brows’ bent bent, and none of our parts were so poor, but it was a race of heaven.

column1: Unto the dignity and height of fortune, The high imperial type of this earth’s glory.
column2: The high imperial type of this earth’s glory is to the dignity and height of fortune.

column1: My lord!
column2: My lord!

column1: Comfort me.
column2: Be calm.

column1: As birds do, Mother.
column2: As birds do, Mother.

column1: You thought because he could not speak English in the native garb, he could not therefore handle an English cudgel.
column2: You thought because he couldn’t speak English in the native language, he couldn’t handle an English cudgel.

column1: Not so, my lord.
column2: Not true, my lord.

column1: Where is he?
column2: Where is he?

column1: Boy, this shall not excuse the injuries That thou hast done me.

column1: Shut doors after you.
column2: Shut the doors after you.

column1: Wilt come?

column1: My voice is now the king’s, my looks mine own.
column2: My voice is now the king’s voice, and I look like my own.

column2: I have as much of my father in me as you, though I admit you’re closer to his reverence.

column1: Drown cats and blind puppies!
column2: Drowning cats and blind puppies!

column1: Cassio, may you suspect Who they should be that have thus mangled you?
column2: Cassio, do you think they should be the ones who have mangled you?

column2: King Lear has lost his daughter and he has lost his daughter.

column1: Think upon these gone.

column1: So.
column2: That’s true.

column1: Yea, but so I am apt to do myself wrong.
column2: Yes, but I’m apt to do myself wrong.

column2: If you’re out of my honor and in my greatness, you’ll die.

column2: My lord?

column2: If he’s coming tomorrow, I’ll pay him.

column2: My dear Othello!

column1: If she do, he’ll smile and take ’t for a great favor.
column2: If she does, he’ll smile and take it for a great favor.

column2: I’m sure it’s to knight you, Captain.

column1: Come, Charmian.
column2: Come on, Charmian.

column1: And will you, being a man of your breeding, be married under a bush like a beggar?
column2: And will you be married under a bush like a beggar?

column2: We’re not going to run, Monsieur Monster.

column1: Tedious it were to tell and harsh to hear.
column2: It’s too bad to tell and too harsh to hear.

column1: What, and my old Venetian friend Salerio?
column2: What, and my old Venetian friend Salerio?

column1: Has he, masters?
column2: Has he, masters?

column1: Cannot a plain man live and think no harm, But thus his simple truth must be abused With silken, sly, insinuating jacks?
column2: Can’t a plain man live and think no harm, but he must be abused with silky, sly, insinuating jacks?

column1: Bid them achieve me and then sell my bones.
column2: Tell them to get me and then sell my bones.

column1: Why, then All Souls' Day is my body’s doomsday.
column2: Well, then, All Souls’ Day is my body’s doomsday.

column1: For naught so vile that on the earth doth live But to the earth some special good doth give.
column2: It’s so vile that on earth only some special good is given to the earth.

column1: And shall, sir.
column2: And will, sir.

column1: They did so, to th' amazement of mine eyes That looked upon ’t.
column2: They did so, to amaze me how I looked at it.

column1: He is, indeed, sir, the most skillful, bloody, and fatal opposite that you could possibly have found in any part of Illyria.
column2: He is indeed the most skillful, bloody, and fatal man you could find in any part of Illyria.

column1: And here much Orlando.
column2: And here’s much Orlando.

column1: Tell me in sadness, who is that you love.
column2: Tell me in sadness who you love.

column1: You would lift the moon out of her sphere if she would continue in it five weeks without changing.
column2: You’d lift the moon out of her sphere if she continued in it for five weeks without changing it.

column1: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?
column2: Would you do such a thing for all the world?

column1: Well run, Thisbe!
column2: Good run, Thisbe!

column1: No seconds?
column2: No seconds?

column1: I will not have to do with you.
column2: I won’t have to deal with you.

column2: Will your Honor enjoy these conserved goods?

column2: You can’t take from me any thing I’ll do more willingly—except my life, except my life, except my life.

column1: Come.
column2: Come on.

column1: Richmond is on the seas.
column2: Richmond is on the seas.

column1: Brother, I advise you to the best.
column2: Brother, I advise you to the best.

column1: Pray you, hasten Your generals after.
column2: Please hurry up your generals.

column1: Would you had never seen him!
column2: You wish you had never seen him!

column1: Why, know’st thou any harm’s intended towards him?
column2: Why, do you know any harm is intended for him?

column1: So every bondman in his own hand bears The power to cancel his captivity.
column2: So every bondman in his own hand has the power to cancel his captivity.

column1: The pig, or the great, or the mighty, or the huge, or the magnanimous are all one reckonings, save the phrase is a little variations.
column2: The pig, or the great, or the mighty, or the huge, or the magnanimous are all one thing, except the phrase is a little different.

column1: This murderous shaft that’s shot Hath not yet lighted, and our safest way Is to avoid the aim.
column2: This murderous shaft that’s been shot hasn’t been lighted yet, and our safest way is to avoid the aim.

column2: You’ll see her window entered the night before her wedding day.

column1: Do not then walk too open.
column2: Don’t walk too open.

column1: That’s her torment.

column1: I am bound to thee forever.
column2: I’m bound to you forever.

column2: Go shake your ears!

column1: And then, I hope, thou wilt be satisfied.
column2: And then, I hope, you’ll be satisfied.

column1: And laid the love juice on some true love’s sight.

column2: Well, then, tell me: women can fall when men have no strength.

column1: Nay, I hope.
column2: No, I hope so.

column1: Bind fast his corky arms.
column2: Bind his corky arms.

column1: Let go my hand.

column1: It is, and wants but nomination.
column2: It is, and it wants to be renamed.

column1: And this our life, exempt from public haunt, Finds tongues in trees, books in the running brooks, Sermons in stones, and good in everything.
column2: And this life, exempt from public haunts, finds tongues in trees, books in the running brooks, Sermons in stones, and good in everything.

column1: My back a' t' other side.

column1: Her vestal livery is but sick and green, And none but fools do wear it.
column2: Her robes are sick and green, and no fools wear it.

column1: Kent, sir, the banished Kent, who in disguise Followed his enemy king and did him service Improper for a slave.
column2: Kent, sir, the banished Kent, who disguisedly followed his enemy king and did him service as a slave.

column1: How doth the lady?
column2: How is the lady?

column1: Here comes a messenger.
column2: Here comes a messenger.

column1: But I have, sir, a son by order of law, some year older than this, who yet is no dearer in my account.
column2: But I have a son, sir, who is a little older than this, who is still no dearer than me.

column1: Prithee, listen well.
column2: Please listen well.

column1: He meant he did me none; the more my spite.
column2: He meant he didn’t do anything for me, the more I did.

column1: Her eyes are fierce, but thine Do comfort and not burn.
column2: Her eyes are fierce, but you’re comforting and not burning.

column1: Filths savor but themselves.
column2: Filths only savor themselves.

column2: Don’t say any more.

column2: Oh, I’ve suffered with those who I saw suffer.

column2: Oh, sir, I won’t be so hard-hearted.

column1: How now, my metal of India?

column1: Oh, how he loves Caesar!
column2: Oh, how he loves Caesar!

column1: The time of universal peace is near.
column2: The time of universal peace is approaching.

column1: Had our general Been what he knew himself, it had gone well.
column2: If our general had been what he knew himself, it would have been good.

column1: A rarer spirit never Did steer humanity, but you gods will give us Some faults to make us men.
column2: A rarer spirit never helped guide humanity, but you gods will give us some faults to make us men.

column1: But let me to my fortune and the caskets.
column2: But let me go to my fortune and the caskets.

column1: Sometimes from her eyes I did receive fair speechless messages.
column2: Sometimes she saw me receiving speechless messages from her eyes.

column1: Of love?

column1: She’s gone forever.
column2: She’s gone forever.

column1: I say, it is not lost.
column2: I say, it’s not lost.

column1: He speaks well.

column2: Romeo will thank you, daughter, for both of us.

column1: Why, all these should be in the lanthorn, for all these are in the moon.—But silence!

column2: Don’t make denial.

column2: He’s sure to be possessed, madam.

column2: You, uncivil lady, have breathed out my ingrate and unauspicious altars that have been poured out by the faithful, whose devotion has been redeemed—what should I do?

column2: She gave it to me, dying, and told me to give it to her when my fate would have me.

column2: I can’t draw a cart or eat dried oats.

column2: My banquet is to close our stomachs up after our great good cheer.

column2: Ratcliffe, come to my tent around midnight and help me arm me.

column2: Have you lost your wits?

column2: This dagger has mista’en—for his house is empty on the back of Montague, and it’s misheathed in my daughter’s bosom.

column2: This was the most unkind cut of all.

column2: The merchandise you’ve brought from Rome are all too dear for me.

column1: I’ll go and chat with Paris.
column2: I’ll go and chat with Paris.

column2: You are their heir, you sit on their throne, and the courage and blood that redeemed them are running in your veins.

column2: Come, Hamlet, come and take this hand from me.

column1: And welcome more common, for that’s nothing but words.
column2: And welcome is more common, because that’s nothing but words.

column1: Your loss is as yourself, great, and you bear it As answering to the weight.
column2: Your loss is as good as yours, and you bear it as you’re answering to the weight.

column1: We will hear Caesar’s will.
column2: We’ll hear Caesar’s will.

column1: Oh, ay, as summer flies are in the shambles, That quicken even with blowing.
column2: Oh, yes, as summer flies are in the shambles, that’s just like blowing.

column1: Do so, and bid my sweet prepare to chide.
column2: Do so, and tell my sweet to prepare to scold me.

column1: I shall attend you presently at your tent.
column2: I’ll be at your tent.

column1: For, my good liege, she is so idly kinged, Her scepter so fantastically borne By a vain, giddy, shallow, humorous youth, That fear attends her not.
column2: My good liege, she’s so kinged, her scepter is so fantastically borne by a vain, giddy, shallow, humorous youth that she doesn’t have any fear.

column1: Is your Englishman so expert in his drinking?
column2: Is your Englishman so expert in his drinking?

column1: Edmund I think is gone In pity of his misery to dispatch His nighted life; moreover to descry The strength o' th' enemy.
column2: Edmund is gone, I think, in pity of his misfortune to dispatch his night life, and to descry the strength of the enemy.

column1: What early tongue so sweet saluteth me?
column2: What early tongue is that sweet salute for me?

column1: The less they deserve, the more merit is in your bounty.
column2: The less they deserve, the more you deserve.

column1: Indeed?
column2: Yes, really?

column1: I am old and foolish.
column2: I’m old and foolish.

column1: Come, let us to the banquet.
column2: Come on, let’s go to the banquet.

column1: Motley’s the only wear.
column2: Motley’s the only wear.

column1: His affections do not that way tend.
column2: His affections don’t tend to go that way.

column1: Had I plantation of this isle, my lord— He’d sow ’t with nettle seed.
column2: If I had planted this island, my lord— He’d sneezed it with nettle seed.

column1: All’s hushed as midnight yet.
column2: It’s still as hushed as midnight.

column1: I bring thee tidings of the Prince’s doom.
column2: I’ll bring you a story about the Prince’s death.

column1: You may light on a husband that hath no beard.
column2: You can light up a husband who has no beard.

column1: A soothsayer bids you beware the ides of March.
column2: A soothsayer asks you to beware of March’s landslides.

column1: Nor I.
column2: I’m not.

column1: Welcome, good Robin.
column2: Welcome, good Robin.

column1: So the poor third is up, till death enlarge his confine.
column2: So the poor third is up, until death enlarges his confinement.

column1: I pray you.
column2: Please.

column1: Ay, very well, my lord.
column2: Yes, very well, my lord.

column1: I pray thee, tell me then that he is well.
column2: Please tell me that he’s well.

column1: Bid them all fly, For when I am revenged upon my charm, I have done all.
column2: Tell them to fly, because when I’m revenged on my charm, I’ve done everything.

column1: Ah, that good Kent— He said it would be thus, poor banished man.
column2: Ah, that good Kent— He said it would be like that, poor banished man.

column1: You shall be king.
column2: You’ll be king.

column1: The gain I seek is quiet in the match.
column2: I’m looking for a win in the match.

column1: Is he of God’s making?
column2: Is he God’s making?

column1: Why, our battalia trebles that account.
column2: Why, our battalia trebles that.

column1: God made him and therefore let him pass for a man.
column2: God made him, and so he let him pass for a man.

column1: I pray thee, overname them.
column2: Please, overname them.

column1: Oh yes, I saw sweet beauty in her face Such as the daughter of Agenor had, That made great Jove to humble him to her hand When with his knees he kissed the Cretan strand.
column2: Oh yes, I saw sweet beauty in her face as the daughter of Agenor had in her face.

column1: Eight wild boars roasted whole at a breakfast—and but twelve persons there!
column2: Eight wild boars roasted whole at a breakfast—and only twelve people there!

column1: Is in his retirement marvelous distempered.
column2: He’s in his retirement and is a wonderful man.

column1: I have nothing to do with thee.
column2: I have nothing to do with you.

column1: Downy windows, close,
column2: Close, sluggish windows.

column1: We are arrant knaves, all.
column2: We’re arrant knaves, all of them.

column2: Should I go fetch your nightgown?

column1: Sick, oh, sick!
column2: Oh, sick!

column1: We two alone will sing like birds i' th' cage.
column2: We two will sing like birds in the cage.

column2: But I’m not in the position of honor, and I won’t be reconciled until some elder masters, who have known me, have a voice and a precedent of peace to keep my name ungored.

column1: To fetch my poor distracted husband hence.

column2: Do you know me, fellow?

column2: But let me cry for such a loss.

column2: Oh, coward conscience, how do you affect me?

column1: No, that same wicked bastard of Venus that was begot of thought, conceived of spleen, and born of madness, that blind rascally boy that abuses everyone’s eyes because his own are out, let him be judge how deep I am in love.
column2: No, let me judge how deep I am in love.

column1: No more.
column2: Don’t worry.

column1: I will dispatch it straight.

column2: Mark Antony is sitting in Egypt at dinner and won’t make wars without doors.

column2: I wish you had my bones and I had your news.

column2: I’ll give you the comfort I need with all the additions I can.

column2: Where are you, proud Demetrius?

column2: The content, as I understand it, is to blame.

column2: My brother Gloucester’s voice.—Yes, I know your errand.

column1: No.

column2: Who can control his fate?

column2: Now you know my meaning.

column2: I would have made it short, since I was able to tell the whole story and to stop the argument.

column2: God forbid!

column2: I tell you, churlish priest, a ministering angel will my sister be when you’re a howling.

column2: But so soon as the sun’s fading in the farthest east begins to draw the shady curtains from Aurora’s bed, away from light, steals my heavy son home.

column2: Should I tell Caesar what you want from him?

column2: Besides, his cote, his flocks, and his feed bounds are now on sale, and now, because of his absence, there’s nothing you can feed on at our sheepcote.

column1: Caesar?
column2: Caesar?

column1: Who builds his hopes in air of your good looks Lives like a drunken sailor on a mast, Ready with every nod to tumble down Into the fatal bowels of the deep.
column2: Who’s chasing his hopes of good looks lives like a drunken sailor on a mast, ready with every nod to tumble down into the deep.

column1: Use your authority.
column2: Use your authority.

column1: Who’s born that day When I forget to send to Antony Shall die a beggar.
column2: Who’s born that day when I forget to send Antony will die a beggar.

column1: I must hence to wait.
column2: I have to go wait.

column1: I partly feel thee.
column2: I feel a bit more like you.

column1: Since I came hither, Which I can call but now, I have heard strange news.
column2: Since I came here, which I can call “secret” now, I’ve heard strange news.

column1: Where be these knaves?
column2: Where are these knaves?

column1: I had rather have a fool to make me merry than experience to make me sad— and to travel for it, too.
column2: I’d rather have a fool to make me sad than experience to travel for it too.

column1: Care keeps his watch in every old man’s eye, And where care lodges, sleep will never lie.
column2: He’s always in the eye of every old man, and when he’s in the mood, he’ll never lie.

column1: She’s the worse for all this.
column2: She’s the worse for all this.

column1: Romeo!
column2: Romeo!

column1: O spite of spites!
column2: Oh spite of spites!

column1: Tis sport to maul a runner.
column2: It’s a sport to make a runner.

column1: Of it own color too.
column2: It’s own color too.

column1: O bitter consequence That Edward still should live “true noble prince”!
column2: Oh, it’s a bitter consequence that Edward still has to live as a “true noble prince”!

column1: An’t please your Majesty, ’tis the gage of one that I should fight withal, if he be alive.
column2: If you’re not your Majesty, it’s the gage of one I should fight with, if he’s alive.

column1: Why the King of France is so suddenly gone back know you the reason?
column2: Why the King of France is suddenly gone back know you’re wrong?

column1: O noble Emperor, do not fight by sea!
column2: Oh, noble Emperor, don’t fight by sea!

column1: What foul play had we that we came from thence?
column2: What kind of play did we play that we came from here?

column1: Give him the cup.
column2: Give him the cup.

column1: No, truly, for the truest poetry is the most feigning, and lovers are given to poetry, and what they swear in poetry may be said as lovers they do feign.
column2: No, really, because the truest poetry is the most feigning, and lovers are given to poetry, and what they swear in poetry can be said as lovers they feign.

column1: No, rather I will go to Benedick And counsel him to fight against his passion; And truly I’ll devise some honest slanders To stain my cousin with.
column2: No, I’ll go to Benedick and advise him to fight against his passion.

column1: When we have matched our rackets to these balls, We will in France, by God’s grace, play a set Shall strike his father’s crown into the hazard.
column2: When we’ve matched our rackets to these balls, we’ll play a set in France, by God’s grace, that will strike his father’s crown into the danger.

column1: Surely, a princely testimony, a goodly count, Count Comfect, a sweet gallant, surely!
column2: Yes, a good count, Count Comfect, a sweet gallant, surely!

column1: Do you quarrel, sir?
column2: Do you have a fight, sir?

column1: I am the youngest of that name, for fault of a worse.
column2: I’m the youngest person in that name, because I’m a worse person.

column1: But, Audrey, there is a youth here in the forest lays claim to you.
column2: But Audrey, there’s a young man in the forest who claims to you.

column1: It cannot be but thou hast murdered him.
column2: It can’t be that you’ve murdered him.

column1: You sent me for a rope’s end as soon.
column2: You sent me for a rope’s end as soon as you got it.

column1: Oh, then belike you fancy riches more.
column2: Oh, then you’ll get more riches.

column1: Marian, I say!
column2: Marian, I say!

column1: Yon light is not daylight, I know it, I.
column2: I know that light is not daylight, I know.

column1: That, sir, which I will not report after her.
column2: That, sir, which I won’t report after her.

column1: I prithee, tell me who is it quickly, and speak apace.
column2: Please tell me who it is quickly, and speak quickly.

column1: Who’s there?
column2: Who’s there?

column1: Why, what are you?
column2: What are you doing?

column1: True, noble prince.
column2: True, noble prince.

column1: Season your admiration for a while With an attent ear, till I may deliver, Upon the witness of these gentlemen, This marvel to you.
column2: I’ll give you this marvel, upon the witness of these gentlemen.

column1: Madam, I am not well.
column2: Madam, I’m not well.

column1: Will you hoist sail, sir?
column2: Will you hoist sail, sir?

column1: God knows I loved my niece, And she is dead, slandered to death by villains That dare as well answer a man indeed As I dare take a serpent by the tongue.— Boys, apes, braggarts, jacks, milksops!
column2: God knows I loved my niece, and she is dead, slandered to death by villains that dare as well answer a man as I dare take a serpent by the tongue.— Boys, apes

column1: God’s will and His pleasure, Captain, I beseech you now, come apace to the king.
column2: God’s will and pleasure, Captain, I beg you now to come to the king.

column1: Why, what should be the fear?
column2: Why, what’s the fear?

column1: Tybalt is dead, and Romeo banishèd.”
column2: Tybalt is dead, and Romeo has been banned.”

column1: Am I the motive of these tears, my lord?
column2: Am I the reason for these tears, my lord?

column1: Come, Let’s have one other gaudy night.
column2: Come on, let’s have one other gaudy night.

column1: Whither, my lord?—Cesario, husband, stay.
column2: Where are you, my lord?—Cesario, husband, stay.

column1: He may win, And what is music then?
column2: He can win, and what’s music?

column1: O my lord, my lord, Forgive my fearful sails!
column2: Oh, my lord, my lord, forgive my fearful sails!

column1: Will it not be?
column2: Willn’t it be?

column1: They say he has been fencer to the Sophy.
column2: They say he’s been a fencer to the Sophy.

column1: I shall do’t, my lord.
column2: I’ll do it, my lord.

column1: Why let it strike?
column2: Why should it strike?

column1: Give him heedful note.
column2: Give him a note.

column1: Too long a pause for that which you find there.
column2: It’s too long for the things you’re looking for.

column1: Murder?
column2: Murder?

column1: E’en as the o’erflowing Nilus presageth famine.
column2: The Nile is a pretext for famine.

column1: Nay, you must name his name, and half his face must be seen through the lion’s neck.
column2: No, you have to name his name, and half his face must be seen through the lion’s neck.

column1: Your eldest daughters have fordone themselves, And desperately are dead.
column2: Your eldest daughters have forgiven themselves, and are desperately dead.

column1: The crowner hath sat on her and finds it Christian burial.
column2: The crowner has sat on her and finds it Christian burial.

column1: And when I told thee he was of my counsel Of my whole course of wooing, thou cried’st “Indeed?” And didst contract and purse thy brow together As if thou then hadst shut up in thy brain Some horrible conceit.
column2: And when I told you he was a good man, you cried “Indeed?” And you sat and pursed your brow together as if you had shut up your brain with some horrible conceit.

column1: Who’s there?
column2: Who’s there?

column1: Lord of lords!
column2: Lord of lords!

column1: Who brought it?
column2: Who brought it?

column1: Yes, madam, he was of that consort.
column2: Yes, madam, he was from that consort.

column1: I would not for the wealth of all the town Here in my house do him disparagement.
column2: I wouldn’t punish him for the wealth of the whole town here in my house.

column1: Why, what is Tybalt?
column2: Why, what’s Tybalt?

column1: By heaven, that should be my handkerchief!
column2: I swear, that should be my handkerchief!

column1: To supper?
column2: To supper?

column1: Thy conceit is nearer death than thy powers.
column2: Your conceit is closer to death than your powers are.

column1: Press near and second him.
column2: Press near him and second him.

column1: If fortune be not ours today, it is Because we brave her.
column2: If we don’t have fortune today, it’s because we brave her.

column1: He is already named and gone to Scone To be invested.
column2: He’s already been named and went to Scone to be invested.

column1: Ascend her chamber, hence, and comfort her.
column2: Ascend her room and comfort her.

column1: Sweet-heart!
column2: Sweetheart!

column1: If a Christian do not play the knave and get thee, I am much deceived.
column2: If a Christian doesn’t play the knave and get you, I’m very wrong.

column1: I peseech you heartily, scurvy, lousy knave, at my desires, and my requests, and my petitions, to eat, look you, this leek.
column2: I ask you to eat, look, this leek.

column1: Out.
column2: Out.

column1: All of us have cause To wail the dimming of our shining star, But none can help our harms by wailing them.— Madam, my mother, I do cry you mercy; I did not see your Grace.
column2: We all have reason to wail the dimming of our shining star, but none of us can help our harms by wailing them.—Mame, my mother, I cry you mercy; I didn’t see

column1: Was ever man so 'rayed?
column2: Was a man ever so rayed?

column1: My name is Thidias.
column2: My name is Thidias.

column1: For Pyramus therein doth kill himself.
column2: Pyramus is killing himself.

column1: O love!
column2: Oh love!

column1: You are looked for and called for, asked for and sought for, in the great chamber.
column2: You’re in the great chamber looking for and called for, asked and sought for.

column1: They that reap must sheaf and bind, Then to cart with Rosalind.
column2: The people who reap must sheaf and bind, then to cart with Rosalind.

column1: If this uncouth forest yield anything savage, I will either be food for it or bring it for food to thee.
column2: If this unnatural forest gives you anything savage, I’ll either be food for it or bring it to you.

column1: How do you, pretty lady?
column2: How are you, pretty lady?

column1: Out, alas!
column2: Out, sorry!

column1: But yet I feel I fear.
column2: But I’m still afraid.

column1: This blows my heart.
column2: This blows my heart.

column1: Father, what news?
column2: Father, what news do you have?

column1: Away!
column2: Go away!

column1: When Caesar says, “do this,” it is performed.
column2: When Caesar says “do this,” it’s performed.

column1: Why is Time such a niggard of hair, being, as it is, so plentiful an excrement?
column2: Why is time such a naughty nut of hair, as plentiful as it is?

column1: I pray thee, get us some excellent music, for tomorrow night we would have it at the Lady Hero’s chamber window
column2: Please, get us some excellent music, because tomorrow night we’ll have it at Lady Hero’s bedroom window.

column1: Fare thee well, nymph.
column2: Goodbye, nymph.

column1: You are welcome, sir, to Cyprus.
column2: You’re welcome to Cyprus, sir.

column1: Why are you virtuous?
column2: Why are you virtuous?

column1: Didst thou not fall out with a tailor for wearing his new doublet before Easter?
column2: Didn’t you fall out with a tailor for wearing his new doublet before Easter?

column1: Here’s the smell of the blood still.
column2: Here’s the smell of blood still alive.

column1: Up so.
column2: That’s right.

column1: Oh, Oh, Oh!
column2: Oh, Oh, Oh!

column1: I do but keep the peace.
column2: I’m only keeping the peace.

column1: Canst thou so daff me?
column2: Can you help me so badly?

column1: Let him cry, “Praise and glory on his head!” For forth he goes and visits all his host, Bids them good morrow with a modest smile, And calls them brothers, friends, and countrymen.
column2: He’ll cry, “Praise and glory on his head!” He’ll go back and visit all his host, he’ll give them good morning with a modest smile, and call them brothers, friends, and country

column1: Well, I will call Beatrice to you, who I think hath legs.
column2: Well, I’ll call Beatrice to you, who I think has legs.

column1: Now she’s gone for ever.— Cordelia, Cordelia, stay a little.
column2: Now she’s gone for forever.—Curtelia, Cordelia, stay a little longer.

column1: Your man and you are marvelous merry, sir.
column2: Your man and you are wonderful, sir.

column1: They are about the court, And, as I think, they have already order This night to play before him.
column2: They’re on the court, and I think they’ve already ordered this night to play with him.

column1: Only myself stood out; For which, if I be lapsèd in this place, I shall pay dear.
column2: I stood out, and if I’m thrown in this place, I’ll pay dear.

column1: Thou dost not mark me.
column2: You don’t mark me.

column1: Yet say I, he is in love.
column2: But say I, he’s in love.

column1: And wherefore doth Lysander Deny your love, so rich within his soul, And tender me, forsooth, affection, But by your setting on, by your consent?
column2: And why does Lysander refuse to love you, so rich in his soul, and tender me, forsooth, affection, but by setting on, by your consent?

column1: Mistress, both man and master is possessed.
column2: Mistress, both man and master are possessed.
